Any particular place you'd like to go?
Hundreds of places. Paris, Rome, London, Prague, Istanbul, Fez -- Have you ever been to Fez?
I can't say that I have.
I want to go to Fez.
I think travelling for a young girl is a very important thing. Your mother never got a chance to travel much.
I know. She talks about that all the time.
We've got a deal. When I graduate from high school we're going to go backpacking through Europe together. You know, do the whole hostel thing. I just hope it really happens.
Well we'll just have to make sure that it does.
(A golf cart pulls up beside them.
Aren't you sweet? Is Emily here?
No, I'm taking my granddaughter for a round of golf.
Now, we'll meet back here in forty minutes?
And then, if you like, we can get some lunch.
And I'm telling him I've been coming here for twenty years my young friend, and for twenty years that cart, number 43, has been my golf cart.
Did he give you the cart?
Damn right he gave me the cart.
You should have never had to ask because he should have known that.
Heard about your golf cart. Too bad.
Yeah, well, I'm still angry about it.
Richard, who was that young lady I saw you on the golf course with?
You're lucky. My granddaughter looks like she just fell off a potato truck.

My granddaughter would never be caught here. Might get in the way of the time spent at the tattoo parlor or getting something pierced or doing whatever she does while she runs wild through the streets like a rabid dog.
Cut her off! That would get her attention!
I can help you with the litigation.
Said she wanted to learn golf. I think she's taken to it quite well.
Yeah, well, just as long as isn't taken with a certain golf cart.
I'm writing a letter to the board.
I wish you would. If they would take --
(The men go back to their golf cart discussion. Cut to the women's steam room. Rory listens to the gossip.
And you know she took the house.
She deserved it -- putting up with that tramp all those years.
Last year, Christmas, he bough them both the same bracelet.
She should have just shot him like his first wife did.
Oh I love Janie. Is she out yet?
Oh, I just came for the steam. We must get together and play sometime soon.
(Cut to the inn. The staff is still decorating for the wedding.
OK, I need more tulle here. I need the feeling of a major tutu, OK? Oh, uh, hey, Gary, Gary! The ribbons go on the chairs, OK, not on the trees. Oh, great!
(Lorelai hears swans and goes down to meet the truck.
Where do you want the swans?
Well do you know where the pond is?
You know that little road you came up?
OK. Do you know how to say 'big help' in Chinese?
Michel! (to Swan Guy) This is twenty swans?
Yeah. I need you to show this guy where to put the swans.
Well I can't leave, OK? I've got a major tulle festival going on out here.
I will never go near those filthy birds.
No, all swans. I was attacked by a band of swans in the Luxembourg Gardens when I was a boy. No one forgets that.
(laughing) Oh no -- not being attacked by a band of swans. Was it an all-boy band? Kind of a scary, feathery 'N Sync kind of fiasco?
No, I'm sorry, it's not. It's not funny at all.
(laughing) Oh my God! Come on, you have to admit, that's a little funny.
Hey, Pepe le Pew, you wanna give me a hand with this?
Listen, it's Drella or the swans.
So either one beast of terror or another?
What the hell is he babbling about?
Of course he is. He's French.
(to Swan Guy) OK, I'll take you to the pond.
But stay far away from me.
(Drella watches as Michel leads Swan Guy away.
Can't stand the talk -- love to watch the walk.
(Cut to the dining room at the country club.
She caught him in the pool house with the tennis pro, not the riding instructor.
That committee of yours is not looking at people as much as you think.
Why would they? From what you've told me they're all involved in one nefarious activity after another.
It's Peyton Place. Is there more?
OK, Mr. Neville likes all things frilly.
I don't think one will affect the other.
(Man #1 and Man #2 or 3 approach the table.
Look who's here. Ah, Rory, this is Julian Johnson (MAN #1) and Edward James (MAN #2 or 3)
Would you like to join us?
If Rory doesn't mind us intruding on her time with her grandfather.
Oh that's good. So, we hear you're attending Chilton.
Fez? What the hell is in Fez?
That's for her to find out.
(Cut to Luke's. Rory is waiting for Luke.
I went golfing with my grandfather today.
Did you know that golf courses are an environmental blight because of the chemicals they use to keep the grass green?
Actually I did. (silence) Bad joke, sorry.
(Luke walks away just before Lorelai comes in the door.

My God -- this day. The swans, the tulle, my head...Luke, I need the largest cheeseburger in the world. Let's break a record here, mister. (to Rory) So, the wedding is a nightmare. We got these ten boxes of creepy larvae that are supposed to swarm into beautiful butterflies on the wedding day. They swarmed a little early! What's with the hat?
So, Rory's golfing adventure. Tell me!
Oh, honey, I brought you some of Sookie's chocolate cake to make you feel better.
You are the sweetest kid in the whole world. Where on earth did you get that from? Luke, am I mistaken or did that sign on the door say "open"? (to Rory) So, where were we?
OK, well, uh, by the end of the day I could even hit the ball. Sometimes it wasn't my ball but the intentions were good.
Well good intentions and no physical exertion whatsoever is what the game of golf was built on. So, um, did you order?
I'm not hungry. I had a big lunch at the club.
With all the other devastators of our land.
You had a big lunch at the club?
I've said quite plenty of times.
Whatever. So besides the "quite good" lunch you had, what else happened?
Nothing. We played, I met his friends, I took a steam.
Yeah. I sweated out all my toxins and I stole a towel.
Wow! Sounds like you really had a good time.
Sorry -- I just -- I'm surprised. I thought you were gonna be bored.

I’m gonna miss the test! [comes out with her uniform over her t-shirt and jogging pants, putting on her shoes]
No you’re not [Shoves a binder into Rory’s school bag and give it to her] I’ll get the keys. We’ll go right now. Let’s go! Let’s go! [grabs her purse] Oh!! I can’t take you!
I have a meeting at the inn at 8!
Ok, wait. Ok. Think, listen. Here, you drive.
Yeah, you drive. I’ll get a ride with Sookie. Take the phone, take the keys, go!
[She stops at a stop sign and calls Lane who’s listening to music
Did I leave a set of my notes at your house yesterday?
I’m driving to school. I need to check something and I can’t find some of my notes.
Ok, hold on let me check [comes out of her closet and looks around her room] I don’t see anything.
What did I do with them?
Well, maybe it’s downstairs in the store?
Maybe I just - [loud bang and car moved]
I just got hit by a deer.
No! I got hit by a deer!
How do you get hit by a deer?
I was at a stop sign and he just hit me! Oh my God! [Getting out to look for deer]
I don’t know. I don’t know what to ask after you’ve been hit by a deer.
Well put salt down. Deers love salt.
Where am I gonna get salt from?
I don’t see him any where. [as she tries to take off her jogging pants] What if he’s hurt.
No! [runs back to the car with one pant leg on, one off.]
[Rory’s running down the hall pulling her socks up, taking out her ponytail ad tucking in her shirt
Everyone back to your tests. Miss Gilmore you’re gonna have to wait in the library.
I’m afraid you’ve missed the test.

script.character: Max: we start class promptly at 8

script.text: That’s when I need people to be in their seats.
I’m sorry but it’s the rules.
But you don’t understand! I was up all night studying and then I missed my bus so I had to drive--
So I’m driving down this road and I stop and I get hit by a deer.
No I got hit by a deer. You don’t believe me? I’ve got antler prints on the side of my mother’s car.
No! You have to let me take this test. I’m ready for this test. I know everything there is to know about Shakespeare.
Ok, ok, you have to calm down now.
I know his birthday and his mothers name and that kind of -

[turning around to her] And just what is wrong with you huh?! You already have everything! You already have the grades and the status. What the hell is wrong with you that you have this constant need to be the biggest jerk in the entire world?!
Huh?! What’s ?! What’s up quippy?! Why so silent?
And for the last time - the name’s RORY!
Make sure that carpet is replaced perfectly before they go
I mean perfectly. Nailed down and everything.

Oh you mean that perfectly. Oh I thought you meant the other perfectly. You know the one that could be misinterpreted by the other Michel. You know the one who couldn’t understand what you meant by perfectly. [Lorelai closes book and leaves]
Hey what do you think about Pat Benatar?
Great idea, can she play the harp?
Whoo! Whoo-hoo!! [Sookie is dancing around in the kitchen] I knew it! I knew it! I knew it! I knew it! I knew it! [Lorelai comes in] I found it, I found it!
His bill! I found his bill!
It wasn’t the risotto, it was the wine! He ordered the wrong wine!

See in the review, he mentioned something about a summer tomato salad which I’ve only made once in the last 3 weeks because Jackson of course decides to get into a fist fight with his tomato grower - that’s a different story.
Yes - save it for Christmas time.
So Brian, the goatee waiter, only worked one shift last week because his girlfriend kicked him out and he had to move.
But she knew that when they moved in.
Women always think they can change men.
So anyhow, I checked the dates, I narrowed the day down and I found a party that had ordered practically everything on the menu including -
Yes, the risotto and a riesling. Ha! A riesling
Why not just drink battery acid.
Exactly! Changes the entire flavor of the dish. And the fact that Brian even served it makes me think Celia is a little bit better off without him.
I’m so glad hon, oh! [they hug giggling]
[Sookie takes one and looks at it
Oh, it’s good to have her back huh
Yeah [pause] You’re still gonna have to pay for the zucchini
[Lorelai smiles. Turns to go as Michel comes in
There is a man with a funny accent on the phone asking for you.
Really? Did you guys exchange the secret handshake? [giggles with Jackson] Lorelai here [into the phone]
I got hit by a deer.
And then I was late and they wouldn't let me take the test.
They wouldn’t let me take the test so I -
No, it’s ok. Just sit right here, I’ll handle this.
[Goes into Headmaster Charleston’s office. Pan to inside Headmaster’s office
Um, I think there’s been a terrible mistake. Rory told me that she wasn’t allowed to take her test.
Right, well, see there were circumstances beyond her control. Rory is never late. She’s almost annoyingly on time. I think if you checked your records -
Past performance has nothing to do with today’s situation.
Ok, but see, she was up all night studying, I was there, she has a witness.
Well your honor [pause] just a little trial humor, that won’t happen again. Um, see, she got up late, she broke her neck to get here. We don’t like locally as you know.
My computer crashed and I lost my midterm.
My grandmother and 1st cousin died. My sister took my report to school instead of hers, my religion prohibits studying after sundown. I went blind last night but I’m fine now.
[getting up] Ms. Gilmore, rules are rules. When you’re late, you forfeit the right to take the test.
Where are you going? [to Max] Where is he going?
Lorelai please, believe me if I could do anything I would.
Yes, you could let her take the test.
Ms. Gilmore, we are not here to be fair, we are here to educate.
Yes and I’m asking you to please educate my kid.
We will, when she’s on time. Have a nice day.
Are you holding that door open for a reason?

Do you have any idea what we have gone through this week? We have been up all night every night studying. We haven’t slept. We haven’t talked about anything else except this school and this test for seven days. We have stretched ourselves as thin as humanly possible without going completely postal. My God! We’re only one person!
Why don’t we narrow our field conversation down to Rory.

Ok, yeah, why don’t we. You sit up here in your snotty little school that’s in desperate need of some extra heating vents and you nurture horrible kids who treat each other like mortal enemies. You set impossible standards that make normal people feel less than everyone else. And you take a great kid like Rory and you tear her apart!
I don’t think that’s completely fair.

[to Max] And you! You say she’s smart and she’ll be fine and this rotting stodgy rathole could use somebody like her and then you completely shut her out of a test that she’s crammed for, that she’s ready for, that she completely deserves to take!
I didn’t call this place a ‘rathole’

Oh no that’s true. I added that. Wouldn’t want you to get in trouble with ‘Il duce’ here. I thought this place was going to be so great! And now I guess this goes on the ‘Boy was I wrong’ list, right above gauchos but just below the ‘Flashdance’ phase.
My goodness you do like to throw fits in your family.
Your daughter threw a similar if not as manic fit of her own this morning.
Please. Rory doesn’t throw fits. She’s the most even tempered person I know.
Well then, she did a lovely impression of you.

Ms. Gilmore, everything you said in your rant was absolutely true - without the colorful embellishments of course. We do set impossible standards, and such standards do foster highly competitive children. However that is life and that is Chilton.
Rules can change, you can change them.

I told your daughter when she came here that this place was not for everyone and might not be for her. I will now tell you the same thing. She doesn’t have to be here. She doesn’t have to go to Harvard, maybe she shouldn’t if she can’t handle the pressure, she should leave. Now you can take your daughter home now and decide what it is you intend to do. However, another outburst from either of you will not be on the options list. Thank you for coming in. That will be all.
You got hit by a deer?
You did! You got hit by a deer.
It just came out of nowhere.
You couldn’t just run into a wall like other kids.
Can we just go home please.
CUT TO SOOKIE OUTSIDE OF LUCENT MILLS HOUS
Yes, hello [with her back to him] My name is Sookie St. James, I’m
the chef at the Independence Inn
You do? Well, I’m flattered, you write about a lot of chefs -
Right. Well I know that this is a terrible intrusion but - are you cooking?
No wait. I found out your address from my network of culinary friends -
Look, this is really inappropriate. I gave you a good review, I suggest you go home.
I don’t care about the review. I just - I want you to try this disk, with this wine [handing them to him still with her back turned] I’ll wait.
CUT TO LORELAI AND RORY DRIVING HOM
You know, I just think that we should talk about it.
You’re just feeling like an impromptu nature walk?
I wanna see if it’s ok.
Sweetie you’re never gonna find the deer.
It’s dangerous in the car with all the kamikaze deer running around [getting out of car]
Alright, wait up! So what does the deer look like? Huh? Does it have any distinguishing marks - besides the word ‘Jeep’ imprinted on it’s forehead.
I had a nice chat with Headmaster Charleston today. He said you went ballistic in class.
You wouldn’t have been so tired if you hadn’t been killing yourself all week.
I was studying, I didn’t have a choice.
Well maybe you shouldn’t be studying that hard.
You’re 16. You should get some sleep and eat a real meal and come up for air once in a while.
No, of course not. They love you. This is coming from me.
Are you saying I should quit?
I’m saying, if you wanted to go back to your other school with Lane, that would be fine with me.
You don’t think I can do it.

You know that’s not true. I think you can do anything. But you don’t lose it in class. That’s not part of the Rory personality description and if you’re losing it in class because you’re tired or stressed or working to hard, I’m worried about that. I have to be.
Ok, fine. It’s just I can’t remember, you know, a time when we weren’t talking about you going to Harvard. It was just a given, that what we were working for. Everything went in that direction.
And I’m forgetting where all that started.
I’m talking about - did it start with me? Or did it start with you? Was it my dream that you go to Harvard.
Because I never got to do the big fancy college thing? Maybe all this time I’m thinking it’s all for Rory, when really it wasn’t.
I’m not doing this because of you.
Because if you are, you don’t have to.
I’ll still love you. Even if you can’t support me in my old age in the fabulous manner to which I plan on growing accustomed.
Thank you. I just want you to be happy.
No, I want you to be ‘dancing through the woods crazy’ happy. And if Chilton and Harvard is not gonna do that for you, then forget about them.
I was just behind. I never caught up with all the reading. That’s why I got a ‘D’. I can catch up. I will catch up and when I do, everything will be fine.
You know Harvard is my dream. I want it more than anything, I swear
I appreciate all that you’re saying. I do. But I’m not ready to give up on Chilton yet.
I do however reserve the right to change my mind.
That’s your prerogative as long as you remain a woman.
For yelling at the Headmaster the way you did.
Oh, I didn’t yell at him.
You’re welcome. How much longer are we gonna look for this crazy deer?
Just a little further. I just hope he didn’t hurt himself.
I just hope he has insurance.
Go get that plaid skirt off and grab your books, we’re going to Luke’s.
Don’t you have to get back to work?
Ah, they can last a little while longer without me. Plus Michel gets so cute when he feels like he’s been overworked. His ears puff out, his nostrils flare, big fun. Go.
[voice on answering machine] It’s us, we’re not here. We have a life, get over it.
[Lorelai closes books in the living room as she listens to the message, then sits on the couch

Hi this is a message for Rory. It’s Max Medina calling. I just wanted to say that I talked to Headmaster Charleston or ‘il duce’ as he’s more affectionately know at the Gilmore household, and he’s agreed to let you do some extra credit work to help make up for the missed test today. Now I’m not sure what the extra credit work is yet, but it probably will be time consuming and extremely painful. It will however get you back up to where you rightfully belong Rory, don’t lose heart. Make this work. And if you’re mother is listening, Lorelai it was a pleasure encountering you. I hope it happens again. Anyways, see you in class. Bye.
(Lorelai, Rory, and Emily Gilmore are sitting around the dinner table.
So where'd you say Dad was?
Germany. Is Dad's firm insuring Nazis now?
Your father doesn't know any Nazis.
I know, Mom. I was just --
Oh, I'm afraid I have some bad news. Claudia died.
Claudia. Your cousin Claudia. (Lorelai stares.) Claudia!
I'm hearing the name, Mom. I have no idea who that is.
Claudia's your cousin, for all intents and purposes.
Oh, now we're getting to it.
She was your father's grandmother's sister's girl. So to you, that would make her --
Regardless the funeral's on Thursday. I thought we'd all go together.
Ooh, whoa. Two problems. Impossible to get away from the inn Thursday. Two, I've never met this woman.
We went to her house in Groton to see the first moon landing. She'd just gotten a new Philco.
I have no memory of this whatsoever.
Rory, correct me if I'm wrong, but men have walked on the moon regardless of whether your mother remembers it or not.
I know men have walked on the moon. I just don't know Claudia.
I don't think Claudia's planning to die a second time.
Mom, I couldn't go if I wanted to.
No, a Nazi that we knew. I'd forgotten. We stayed with him once in Munich. Nice old man. Interesting stories.
Mom you socialized with a Nazi? That's despicable! That's heinous!
No, dear, that was a joke.
(Cut to Lorelai's kitchen. It is morning and Lorelai is seated at the table drinking coffee. Rory walks into the kitchen and closes her bedroom door on loud music.
Hey. I have an idea for a new reality show. How about everyone just looks out their freakin' kitchen window for a change?
Let's just say the world has a formidable opponent.
I don't know. Shouldn't you be knitting?
Mom! The Chilton bake sale is today!
I know. I got it covered.
They expect the things to be homemade.
By someone other than Dolly Madison.
I said I have it covered.
All of the parents pitch in so this is really really important. You know that, right?
No, I didn't know that. In that case I don't have it covered. I have it covered! Get your stuff and hit the stereo -- we're late.
(Rory opens her door and we see Lane dancing in the room.
(to Lane) Where does your mother think you are?
Oh, on a park bench contemplating the reunification of the two Koreas.
(Cut to exterior of the house. Lane, Lorelai, and Rory walk down the front steps and start to cross the yard. Lane waves as she runs off.
(Babette and Morey walk by. Morey is pulling a wagon with Cinnamon -- their cat --inside. The wagon has a covering like a baby carriage.
Yeah, Morey made it. Cinnamon's not walking good these days but she still likes her passeggiatas. That's Italian for 'a nice walk.'
Oh God, he makes it sound so sexy.
(points to the covered area) What's that?
Oh it's Cinnamon's private area. Sometimes she likes to be alone. She's just like Morey in that sense. (to Morey) Hey, say passaggiata again.
I can't do it on command, Babs.
Oh, he's blushin'. God, I love a man that blushes!
(BABETTE and MOREY walk away, pulling the wagon.
Okay, our town is just weird.
I'll see you later at school.
Ha! I got the vein in the forehead. Whoo!

(Cut to a busy street. People are walking by on the sidewalk. Rory is sitting on a bench. A bus pulls around the corner and stops in front of her. Dean is walking down the street and sees Rory get on the bus. He gets on and sits behind her. Rory opens her book and beings to read. She doesn't notice him.
I saw you standing in line so I thought I'd say hello. (pause) Hello?
Oh, hey, uh, thanks for helping me get the job at the store. I mean it's not a career or anything but it's got me solvent.
Yeah, uh, are you always this serious?
So, uh, how long does it take you to get to school?
Um...forty minutes if the bus driver's focused but longer if he's trying to win something on the radio. Hey, this bus is going to Hartford!
But you go to school here. You have to get off the bus! (calls to driver) Hey, he has to get off the bus!
Buses make stops. Good-bye Lorelai Gilmore.
(Cut to the inn where Michel is on the phone.
Independence Inn, Michel speaking. Yes, you are confirmed. Mm-hmm. Goodbye.
(Michel hangs up the phone as a group of businessmen approach the counter.
Bonjour Monsieur. Vous êtes francais? Vous parlez francais?
Sir, I'm just a simple country boy from Texas. I do not understand this francais business you're babbling about.
He knows you're not from Texas.
Michel, I told you there was going to be a French group here for a couple of days and it is your job to keep them happy.
Lorelai, I don't know how many French people you've met over the years, but most of them are insufferable.
Mm-hm. That is why I left France.
Huh. I thought it had something to do with the torches and the villagers. Michel, talk to them.
Never. (pause) You are giving me that look aren't you? Your patented, "Do it or something unspeakable shall befall you" look. (sighs) Fine. I shall be French but I shall not be happy.
Then you will be yourself. Good choice.
(Michel goes back to the French group.
Bonjour messieurs. Je m'appelle Miche. Ce soir pour vous aider.
(laughs) Vous avez faîtt un blague. Très drole! Très drole Michel!
(Cut to the bake sale at Chilton.
OK-- we've got our French fantasies, American treats, and our Italian taste sensations. Well, what do you think?
It is good, isn't it? Well, final touch.
(Sookie prepares to light a swan-shaped dessert on fire.
Whoa, honey, this is a more delicate procedure than you might think, OK?
(SOOKIE lights the tablecloth on fire. Lorelai fills a cup with lemondae from a nearby table and extinguishes the flames. The women at the lemonade table give her dirty looks
Um -- hi. Oh, well, gee...what is that, a dollar? Let me find you a dollar. You know what? I'll take two -- I'll drink one. (drinks) Mmm...tasty and flame-retardant.
Good to see you, Mr. Medina.
Mr. Medina. Meet Sookie, the cheft at the inn. Sookie, Mr. Medina.
I know, you've said it like a zillion times. (to Mr. Medina) Hello.
Hello. Lorelai, could I borrow you for a second?
Oh, yeah, sure. (to Sookie) Oh! Hey I'll be right back.
(Lorelai and Mr. Medina walk away from the table.
You know, Lorelai, I would love for the ice to thaw.
Well you repeated my full name four times. That's ice.
No, that's not ice, it's wintry.
I was doing my job when I didn't let Rory take that test. I didn't like it but I had to do it.
I really do think Rory's a great kid and I'm going to do my damnedest to make sure she gets through Chilton in one piece.
And I'd like us to be friends.
Yeah. Really, truly, I swear. There's no more ice. We're walking in a pool of tepid water.
I'm going to propose something here. I'm not sure how you're going to take it.
I'd like to see you sometime. Away from the ivy, away from the gargoyles, away from here.
Are you asking me out on a date.
Mm. Well, uh, I don't want to go out on a limb here, but I'm guessing if the headmaster won't let a kid be thirty seconds late for a test he'd probably frown on a teacher dating a mom.
I do my job well, I'm dedicated to my students, and there's nothing in the Chilton book of ethics that prohibits it.
Yeah but I'm guessing it's sort of an unwritten rule.
And Rory would probably freak at the thought.
And the other parents would have a field day with this kind of thing.
I can't. It's wrong. It's weird.
I'm kidding. I don't know. You're Rory's teacher.
Could you quit? Right, that's crazy.
OK, OK. Um...how about coffee? You like coffee?

Can we drink some together? A sort of pre-date. Very casual, no strings, no obligations. We'll just see if it's even worth going down the road of including food in the deal. (whispers) Just coffee. (normal voice) Decaf? There's nothing safer than decaf.

script.character: Lorelai: i'm going to be in town tomorrow because i take a class at hartford state and there's a coffee shop across the street that i sometimes, almost all the time, go to around 4:00 and usually exactly 4
script.text: 2. I could not stop a person from entering said establishment around that time, nor would I avoid them if I knew them if they did.
You know the wordsmith thing -- that's something we have in common.
(Cut to Lane and Rory walking down the street.
Philadelphia? If you could live in any city in the world you'd pick Philadelphia?
The guy who directed 'The Sixth Sense.'
But what would you do there?
Hang out with M. Night Shymalan.
OK, cross 'guidance counselor' off your list of potential career choices.
Lie still, baby doll, we're almost home.
Cinnamon's dyspeptic. So's Morey. Too many clams.
This doesn't reflect well on Al's establishment.
Yeah, well we had a coupon.
(Rory and Lane resume walking down the street. Rory spots Dean in the grocery store where he is working.
Oh wow! The store! Hey, listen, I have to pick up some stuff, so --
What do you have to pick up?
Just some...stuff. So I'll talk to you later tonight.
Because otherwise I'd have to go home.
Yeah, actually I don't have to go in.
OK. Then I guess I will go home.
(Lane leaves. Rory walks into the store and watches Dean. He looks over and waves when he sees her. Rory ducks into an aisle and walks to the back of the store where Miss Patty is.
Rory! Hello! Try a plum They're better than sex.
Fresh fruit always has such a sensuality about it. Are you too young for this?
Well what are you here for honey?
Oh, I see what you're here for. Well that wouldn't fit in a basket. No no no no no!
Patty! It's not like that. He's just a person.
I really don't even know him.
Oh, right. You don't know him?
I promise I won't tell a single soul that you don't know that young man.
(Rory walks away from Miss Patty. A store employee confronts Miss Patty, who has been sampling the produce.
Excuse me, ma'am, what are you doing?
Please, honey, don't call me ma'am. It makes me feel older than 25. Here, have a pea pod.
I assume that you're going to pay for the food you've consumed on the premises.
Oh, so brusque. And you are?
I'm the new assistant manager here.
Well listen here, my fine friend, who if you had a better hairstyle i might consider dating, I do this all the time.
Not from now on, I'm sorry.
Oh, now, wait a minute here. I've been sampling food at this establishment for years.
The next time you put something in that mouth that doesn't belong there, I'm going to remove it and then call the police.
(He takes the pea pod out of her hand and walks away. By now Rory is at the check-out counter. Dean walks over to the end of the counter.
Is this all you want, honey? A head of lettuce and a mouse trap?
That's a couple of must-need items there.
I could loan you the rest.
Uh, no, I'll just take the lettuce.
Perfect. You could use half of it for a salad then use the other half to clobber the mouse with.
(Cut to Lorelai entering the coffee shop in Hartford. She sits at the counter near Mr. Medina.

I wanted some cream but that prompted a very elaborate foam conversation. And the look of disapproval I got when I said I didn't want foam, just cream, rivaled the one I got from my dad when I told him I wanted to be a teacher.
Wow, so it's been a tough outing for you, huh?
(The waitress goes to get Lorelai's coffee.
Should we cut the cute and just get right to it?
Because I think we both want to.
Well I want to be in the Bangles but that doesn't mean I quit my job and get a guitar and ruin my life to be a Bangle, does it?
Well it's got to be part of the point if there's no band anymore.
Because we're clearly attracted to each other.
I'm attracted to pie. It doesn't mean I feel the need to date pie.
Wow! Round one and already tapped.
Look I know that you are concerned about the appearance of us dating.
Well I can tell you that I am the soul of discretion when it comes to delicate relationships.
Dated a lot of Chilton moms, huh?
No, I meant any relationships -- work, family.
Oh so you have things to hide in all aspects of your life -- very interesting.
(to waitress) Do you have any hemlock back there? Arsenic, something quick?
Me too. You just telling me what I want to hear?
Doesn't mean it doesn't coincide with how I really feel.
Yeah but if you're telling me what you think I want to hear then I'm not really getting to know you.
And if I know what you want to hear that shows a level of understanding on my part that far exceeds your understanding of me. (Lorelai doesn't say anything). Who's the one laggin?
Wow, round one and already tapped!
(seriously) Rory is my life. She's my pal, my everything. And I would never, ever do anything that would hurt her.
I understand. (A man sits down on the stool between them.) But Rory is not a baby anymore.
Don't say that! She's eight! She's eight and her favorite hobby is making necklaces out of gum wrappers.
You could try stunting her growth, keeping her in a box, blowing cigarette smoke on her.
(The man gives Mr. Medina a strange look.
You are so taking this out of context.
(The man moves to another seat. Mr. Medina moves into the seat next to Lorelai that the man vacated.

OK, when my uncle was a young man, there was this girl who lived across the street from him and he was completely in love with her -- but he never talked to her. But he knew in his gut that this was the girl he wanted to spend the rest of his life with.
This is gonna be sad isn't it?
So anyhow my uncle watches this girl, waiting for the right moment to approach her. Next thing he knows, he gets drafted.

No. Now he thinks 'this is perfect. I'll come back, I'll have a career, I'll have served my country, I'll be worthy of her love.' When he gets back -- she's gone. Moved away. No one knew where and he never saw that girl again. Now my uncle, he didn't say much to me, but the one thing he did say was that if there's something in your gut that you know you feel is right you gotta go after it, no matter what. What do you say?
(Lorelai sighs. She takes out a business card and writes on it.
Maybe dinner wouldn't be so bad.
Dinner? You mean we could sit together? Even drive together?
(Lorelai tosses the card at Mr. Medina.
Hey, that story about your uncle -- is that true?
(Cut to Luke's cafe. Luke serves Lorelai and Sookie.
Thank you. (to Sookie) Life is a funny funny thing, huh?
Yeah I love that Jim Carrey.
Jim Carrey. He's just -- he's just -- funny.
He is funny but I didn't mean funny, funny. I'm being philosophical.
Oh. Very serious face. Jean-Paul Sartre.
I can't talk to you with that face.
How do you guys get any work done?
So why is life such a funy thing?
Yeah there's goody stuff about it but there's baddy stuff too. He's a teacher at Chilton. Max -- you met him at the bake sale.
Yeah. Right. He's so sexy and smart and funny and he likes coffee.
God, he sounds perfect for you. Did you get onions?
(calls to Luke in the kitchen) Hey Luke! You forgot the onions.
I'm just so mixed up though. You know this is a real crossroads kind of situation.It's like 'to perm or not to perm.' I'm really confused.
For Heaven's sake. (Sookie goes around the counter to get the onions. She starts adding things -- onions and spices -- to the other customers' plates.)
Go ahead, I'm still listening. You were about to perm your hair.
I just want to do the right thing.
I'm not sure I see what the problem is.

Oh there are many problems. First -- I do not like to involve Rory in my personal life. I don't want her to have to deal with that. You know, I might bring some guy home and he might not be THE guy but then she gets all attached to him and then all of a sudden I decide that I don't like the way he eats or he hums incessantly or --
Or the way he smacks his lips or how his hair isn't really his.
Yeah. And then I break up with him and then Rory is the one who gets hurt.
This guy is her teacher. I mean, there's no way to keep him out of her life. She sees him every day.
(to a bearded customer) Are you the open-faced turkey?
OK, I added a little fresh lemon and a little cayanne pepper. You're gonna plotz! (to Lorelai) You od know that Rory's not a baby anymore.
I know, that's what he said. Maybe I'm being too serious, right? Maybe I should loosen the rules a bit. Plus, be great to get...you know.
Hey. I was just looking for your paprika.
What have I said about the counter?
How the counter is a sacred space. MY sacred space. You don't do yoga on the Dalai Lama's mat and you don't come behind my counter, period.
Luke takes Sookie by the shoulders and walks her back to the other side of the counter.
(to Lorelai) You bring her again and I want her on a leash. I mean it.
He does make a damn find burger though.
He does at that. Alright I'm just going to keep it simple. I'll tell Rory. If there's even an ounce of weirdenss about it I'll cancel.
No, not oops. The timing hasn't been right. This is a very delicate, fragile situation. It's like one of your souffles. If you don't do it right it's a disaster.
And you have to order it 45 minutes in advance.
Right, I wasn't but speaking directly about your souffle. I was speaking metaphorically.
Oh so you don't like my souffles?

(Cut to Lorelai and Rory pulling into their driveway. They cross the yard and go to Babette's. There is a Stars Hollow Animal Hospital van in the driveway. Inside Babette's house, Cinnamon's body is lying on the floor covered by a sheet. The vet is just standing up as Lorelai and Rory enter the house.
Oh, Lorelai. Come in, come in. She's gone. Cinnamon's gone.
(Rory goes over to Morey and sits next to him.
Is there anything I can do for you, Morey?
This is life, Rory, it breaks your heart.

She looked like she was sleeping. I thought she was asleep so I nudged her and she didn't wake. I gave her a push and she rolled off the couch and since I waxed the floor she went shootin' across the room and then she knocked over the lamp and she still didn't move. I knew it was over. Oh, God, my baby.
Oh, Morey, don't do this to yourself. He thinks it was the clams.
She saw me eating them and she gave me that 'hey, man, what's up?' look and --
It wasn't the clams. Morey, in human years this cat was 260 years old.
Listen, why don't you let me take her out to the van and then I'll get out of your way.
Oh, no, stay. All of you, please stay. Cinnamon would want you here.
We'll stay as long as you want.
(Time lapse. Babette's house is now full of mourners, with more arriving all the time.
They said that they rolled her body into a lamp.
(The bearded customer from the cafe walks by as Michel comes through the door.
Hello? Hello? Where is Lorelai? I'm dropping something off. Yoo-hoo, 'Hee-Haw' man, where is Lorelai Gilmore?
Hey, hey, hey. Thank you. I could not get back to the inn.
What, you are having a party and I was not invited?
Sweetie, it's not a party, it's a wake.
They lick their privates, these cats.
Not the comforting chitchat we're looking for here. Goodbye. I'll talk to you later. Thank you.
(Lorelai pushes Michel out the door just as Miss Patty is pushing her way in.
Babette, Morey, I came as soon as I heard. Oh, darling, what do you need?
(Miss Patty grabs Babette and hugs her and presses Babette's head into her large chest.
(Outside, Sookie and Luke arrive at the same time, both carrying food.
Oh, bless you both! Everyone's starved, come in.
(Sookie and Luke both try to go through the door at the same time and collide. They back up and Sookie rushes in before Luke.
OK, how should we do this?

Well we need a flow for the room so there's no bottlenecks. People coming in, they're gonna want a beverage. Put 'em on the first table then the smaller hors d'oeuvres next to that, leaving one hand free to greet the people. Then, back there, set up plates and cutlery. First the salads, then the meat dishes, then desserts on the piano bench. How does that sound?
Luke dumps his bags of food on a table in the middle of the room.
(Time lapse. Rory answers a knock at the door. It's Dean with his arms full of drinks. He has to duck to get in under the low door frame.
Oh, hi, wow. I wasn't expecting you.
Or me you. I mean, you, me. I mean, come in.
(Dean takes the drinks into the other room. Lorelai walks by.
Well, he goes to my old school, so I see him there sometimes but I go to Chilton now.
RORY; I have to get back
Oh, sure. I'll see you later.
(Dean leaves. While watching him out the window, Rory sees Mr. Medina at her door.
Well, am I in trouble? Did the school call or something?
No, no you're great. I -- um -- let me just come back in just one second.
Let me tell you in a minute.
Max is here to pick me up.
I'm gonna go talk to him real quick and I'm gonna be right back.
(Rory looks upset. Lorelai runs outside and over to her own porch where Mr. Medina is still knocking.
I was knocking but no one answered.
I know. I was at the neighbors' house.
I know it's totally last minute.
I just completely forgot about our date.
No you're memorable. I've been memorabling all week. It's just -- We had a little emergency.
No, Rory's fine. It's the neighbors' cat.
This was a very fat, very beloved cat.
Lorelai. I like you but I don't want to force something on you that you don't want so -- (walks away)
No, no, no. Wait. No, Max, you're not forcing anything on me. I am telling the truth about the cat.
Please don't read that much into this. Call me and we'll reschedule. I promise that's what I want.
Cross my heart and hope no other neighborhood pets die on that day.
(Mr. Medina gets into his car and drives away.
Stupid cat! You couldn't have held on one more day?
You gonna make fun of my mother too?
Sorry. You know, my real-fruit puffs would compliment that dish quite well.
It's fine on its own, thank you.
OK, toss some on the plate.
Can I make a pretty design, maybe make some layers?
Right. Tossing them on. Got it.
You guys, have you seen Rory anywhere?
Yeah, I think she headed that way. (points)
(The grocery store employee from earlier approaches Miss Patty.
Well if it isn't Kirk the jerk.
I want to apologize for what happened at the store yesterday.

I wasn't aware that you were THE Miss Patty. The owner tells me that you're one of our best customers and you can put anything into that mouth that you want to. Those were his words. I could have paraphrased them.
Stop sweating. And close your pores, Kirky, I always forgive.
(Lorelai fins Babette in the kitchen cleaning out a cabinet full of pill bottles.
Oh, hello, sugar. Can I get you something?
No, I'm fine. I'm looking for Rory.
Oh, I think she might be in the bathroom.
Thanks. (starts to leave then stops) Can I help you with something?
Oh, no. I thought I'd just get some of this stuff packed away.
It's like a scene from a kitty version of 'Valley of the Dolls.'
Yeah. You never realize how old they actually are 'til you look in the medicine cabinet.

These were for her heartworms, for her thyroid, her kidneys, for the rash she got from taking these, and these were for the tic she developed from the stuff for the rash. And these -- oh jeez, these are mine. Damn, I'm gonna miss that old broad.
You know, I don't know what I'm gonna do with myself now. You live to take care of your kids.
I know, sweetie, but you gave her everything that you had.
I know. She was so tiny when I got her. She could sleep in my shoe.
The other day I came across a hat that I made for Rory. It was like a doll hat.
Oh, they grow up so fast.
And then they take your clothes.
I guess eventually you have to move on. Figure out what your life is going to be when you're not busy taking care of somebody else. Jeez, look at this place. Not a clean glass in sight!
Let me help you with that.
(They start to wash the glasses but the sink is too low for Lorelai. Babette gets a stool for her.
Here, sugar, use this. Morey sits on it when he helps me.
How does Morey get around in here?
Oh, just fine. He had a couple of concussions his first year here but he never complains. He's just the best thing. I don't know what I'd do without him. (voice breaks)
Oh, Babette. What do you mean 'without him'?
I saw on Oprah a few weeks ago. She had on couples who lost a child. Most of the marriages went belly-up for the pain of it all. Even though they loved each other.
Babette, that is not gonna happen to you.
I never thought a man would ever even want me.
Oh, please, with that ass? Gimme a break.
I mean want me for more than my ass. Me -- for me, the whole package. Annoying neuroses and all.
You'll find him. It might even be that stud who drove out of here in a Mustang.
How is he in the sack?
I haven't even gone out with him yet.
Will you tell me when how he is when you do?
I'll call you during the cigarette.
(They hug. Lorelai hits her head on a low-hanging overhead lamp. They hear [iano music from the other room.

(Cut to the living room. Everyone is seated or standing quietly listening to Morey playing the piano. Miss Patty is beating on a drum. Babette goes over to sit with Morey. Lorelai finds Sookie in the crowd.
Oh I can't find Rory anywhere.
Max showed up for the date that I forgot about and she saw him.
OK, calm down. It's not that big of a deal.
Her teacher showed up on her porch to take out her mother.
She'll understand. You're crazy. She knows that.
(Rory is outside in Babette's yard, surrounded by gnomes. Dean walks up to her.
Yeah, uh, look. I just wanted to say that I'm sorry.

Well I've been kind of bugging you lately. Uh, I thought -- I don't know -- I thought that maybe you liked me. But it's obvious that you're not interested so I just wanted to say that I get it and I'm not gonna bother you anymore.
(Dean starts to leave. Rory gets up and follows him.
(Rory leaves and Dean smiles. As Rory reaches the door Lorelai comes out.
Oh! Finally. I've been looking everywhere for you.
Listen, I have some explaining to do. OK. So sit down in that tiny little chair and I'm gonna do it right now. (Rory sits.) That man on the porch was your teacher.
Mom, I'm a little behind in school but not so far behind that I don't know who the teacher is. So?
So -- um -- he and I were going to sort of hang out together.
No, on a -- something that could appear like a date to the untrained eye.
How long have you been dating him?
I haven't. This was gonna be the first time.
And when were you planning on telling me about this -- your wedding?
No -- by the rehearsal dinner at least.
He teaches me things every day in a very small classroom with a lot of other kids who probably won't be high-fiving me when they find this out.
I knw, sweetie, and I told him this was one of the things I was concerned about.
And he thought we could be discreet.
Information that I should have had.
Information that would have come out eventually. Like the Iran-Contra scandal.
I just can't believe that you didn't tell me about this. Why wouldn't you tell me?
'Cause I thought you were going to take it bad. Thank God I was wrong. (pause) OK, OK. Listen, I'm sorry. I won't date him. I promise.
I'm not saying that you can't date him. It's just -- this is weird. I mean -- there's a million guys in this world and you end up with Mr. Medina.
You think I don't get the weirdness factor? Believe me, the last thing I intended to do was date your teacher.

I really like him, Rory. I can't help it. And it's been a really long time since I've felt like this. You can't always control who you're attracted to, you know. I think the whole Angelina Jolie/Billy Bob Thronton thing really proves that. And I know you don't understand this now but you wil someday. You'll meet some great guy and he'll make your head all foggy and you won't know what to do with yourself. (sighs) Oh, sweetie, I won't keep anything from you again. OK? I promise. From now on every aspect of my life is an open book to you.
Really, I'm not even going to get dressed until I tell you what I'm thinking of wearing.
OK, tomorrow I'm thinking the purple tiger top, the black leather skirt, the panda bear underwear.
But of course I'm totally open to suggestions.
(Lorelai and Rory are leaving Babette's. Babette and Morey walk them out.
Let us know if we can do anything.
Oh, you've done too much already.
Let's stay outside a while, baby. Look for the Big Dipper.
(Morey puts his arm around Babette's shoulders and they watch the sky.
(The phone rings as Rory and Lorelai walk in their front door.
I've been trying to get you all afternoon.
Well there's no messages on the machine, Mom.
I don't leave messages. If I wanted to talk to a machine I'd talk to my VCR. Where were you?
(Rory motions Lorelai not to say it.
Hold on. I'm looking up anyuresm in our medical dictionary to see if I just had one.
I just wanted to be honest with you, Mom. Silly me.
Yeah, a cat. It was a cat's funeral.
You skipped your own cousin's funeral for a cat's funeral?
Not my cousin, mom. My father's grandmother's sister's girl who I've never --
You said you couldn't be away from the inn.
Well I couldn't at the time bt I worked it out.
It's late. I have a big day tomorrow, Mom.
Oh, what? You're going to a racoon's wedding?
Aaagh! She's working for a sedative manufacturer. Keeping that demand sky-high.
Well I don't know what to tell and what to hide.
So we never did quite settle the whole dating-your-teacher issue. I won't go out with him if you don't want me to.
You can go out with whoever you want.
Well I'm certainly not going to go out with him 'cause that would be really weird.
But I mean it. I won't see him if you don't want me to.
You know, if there's anything that makes you feel uncomfortable, big or small, then he's out of there.
Because you know it's not like I'm desperate. I mean, there are plenty of other guys out there.
And it's not like I have to ask your permission. I mean, this is a courtesy.
(Rory goes into her room and closes the door. On the other side of the door, Lorelai raises her voice to be heard.
OK, so I'm going to be up for a while, if you want to get back to me on this.
(Lorelai starts to leave. Rory opens the door and sticks her head out.
Hey, do you think you could keep him out really late on Thursday night because I have this oral exam on Friday that I'd really love him to sleep through.
(Rory, Lorelai, and Emily are at Friday night dinner.
Tomorrow our lawyer, Joseph Stanford, is coming by.
That's terrible. Sissy was a good friend of yours.
Mom, Sissy talked to her stuffed animals and they answered her.
Let's just start a new topic.
She said a new topic, Mom.
Everything's a joke. Everyone's a punch line.
Sorry for that. A little trouble with our China office. Well. What did I miss?
I was being impossible and then I turned into a Jewish comedian.
Uh, Joseph Stanford is coming tomorrow.
Yes. So, Rory, your grandfather and I thought it might be nice after dinner for you to go around the house and pick out what you'd like us to leave you in our wills.
Take a look at that desk in my office. It's a really fine Georgian piece.
Why don't I ever bring a tape recorder to these dinners?
Oh, well, anything you want to leave me is fine.
Nonsense. You should have what you like. So look around and when you see something you like stick a post-it on it.
OK, you two have officially hit a new level of weird that even I marvel at.
You can pick out things too, you know.
Oh, well now it's way less creepy.
Did you hear that Richard? Apparently we're creepy.
(The maid comes in with a tray.
Well if you knew what it was why did you ask?
Oh, I love pudding. I worship it. I have a bowl up on the mantel at home with the Virgin Mary, a glass of wine, and a dollar bill next to it.
I've never had pudding from a crystal bowl before.
Put a post-it on it when you're done.
(Lorelai and Rory are putting post-its on on things in the living room.
So what do we think of this?
I don't know. The Emily and Richard Gilmore Psycho Museum?
This is the strangest evening I've ever spent here.
Great, just getting ready for the big day.
So, um, it's getting late, Mom. Unless you've got some funeral plots for us to decorate we should really be going.
Any special requests for dinner next week?
Mom, I want to talk to you for a minute, and Rory, why don't you go say goodbye to Grandpa...
Yeah, but not there, OK? We got a post-it on that. We'd like to keep it nice.
It must be very exhausting to be you.
Mom, Rory's birthday is next Friday.
So we were thinking that maybe we could push our dinner next week to Saturday.
What are you going to do on Friday?
Well perfect. You'll come here and we'll have a little party.
I was just hoping we could do it another night.
Well why come on another night when her birthday falls on the exact night that you do come here.
Saturday's a pretty good night, Mom.
I'm sorry. Friday nights are my nights. That's what we agreed on when you borrowed money for her school. The rules haven't changed.
Mom, I didn't intend for this loan to become a constant source of blackmail, OK? Now this is my kid's birthday and she will have her party at home on Friday and that's it? End of story.
(Cut to Rory and Lorelai sitting in the car.
So, how would you like two parties this year?
You couldn't get her to cave.
No, but she did agree to make the string quartet to learn "Like A Virgin."
Sweetie, I promise, Saturday night we'll do it up right at home. A Stars Hollow extravaganza.
So, is this party Grandma's having going to be a big deal?
Not really. The government will close that day. Flags will fly at half-mast. Barbra Streisand will give her final concert...again.
Now, the Pope has previous plans, but he's trying to get out of them. However, Elvis and Jim Morrison are coming and they're bringing chips.
(Cut to the inn. Lorelai is in the kitchen with Sookie.
Mini orange biscuits with honey-mustard ham and cheddar cheese.
Oh, did you bring me the picture?
Too bad you couldn't get your mom to relinquish Friday night.
No, she has her Vulcan death grip on that one.
Emily Gilmore -- you could set your watch by her. Oh, you know what she did do last night?
I mean, I'm sure it was some expensive form of pudding, but nonetheless, it was pudding!

Right. That would mean that she actually made a mental note that we liked pudding, which would mean that she actually listened to something other than the judgmental conga line going on in her head, and got over the fact that, to her, pudding is hospital food, and only acceptable when you've just had vital organ ripped out of your body.
Wow, that's some journey she had to take there.
Open your mouth and close your eyes.
Right, sorry. (goes to Sookie) Open your mouth and close your eyes.
Now get ready for something truly amazing.
I don't know. It's like, um...
It's like a berry, but way more exotic.
Jackson, have you been having reactions to your fertilizer fumes again?
For some time now I've been toying with cross-pollination. Finally I've got it. I figured out a way to cross a raspberry with a kumquat.
Kumquat! That's what I taste! Are you serious? How did you do this?
You didn't build one of those machines like in "The Fly" did you? We're not going to find you wandering the streets wearing a raspberry head crying, "eat me!"
(Michel comes in and Jackson walks over to him.
JACKSON You! You can make fun of me all you want to today, 'cause tday I am a god. Today, Mother Nature has bowed down to me
No need to fill me in. I'm quite happy being ignorant of whatever it is that is making him raise his arms over his head.
Oh, hey, Rory's birthday party is Saturday night so start thinking up reasons why you can't come.
I'm going to be out of town.
Oh, you used that last year.
I'll work on it and get back to you
(Cut to Lorelai's house. Rory is on the phone.
'And Justin is just so dreamy. He can't marry Britney, I'll just cry and cry and cry.'
(into the phone) OK, thanks. (hangs up phone) Pizza's on its way.
You're such a good provider. Hi.
I'm going to start my homework. Call me when the pizza guy gets here.
(Rory goes to her room. The phone rings.
Lorelai, what is your work schedule?
I think that goes without saying.
I want to get Rory a birthday present.
Well I'm sure whatever you get her, she'll love.
Yes, but I want to get her something special, something she wants, something...that you would get her.
Oh, OK, fine. You can get her the bong then.
This isn't funny. I hardly to see the girl and we only get to talk at dinner once a week and then it's all about school and Jane.
I thought you might let me into her secret club just this one time and help me buy her something for her birthday.
According to you I'm always serious.

script.character: Emily: well, good, i'll meet you at damion's tomorrow at 3

script.text: (Cut to Chilton. Rory is opening her locker.
I just wanted to say 'happy birthday.'

script.character: Tristin: no, but it will be. (reading from a paper) 'on friday at 4

script.text: (Rory takes the paper. It's an invitation to her birthday party, from Emily and Richard.
I don't know. Everyone in our class, I think.
I'll see you Friday, birthday girl.
My parents are making me go.
(Cut to a department store. Emily points to a hat.
Oh, yeah. As soon as we have her crowned Queen of England we'll give it to her.
Hatwear does that to me. Oh, Mom, look. This is good.
It's a purse shaped like a guitar. This is great.
What will Rory do with that?
She'll put stuff in it. Carry it around.
That she's an ax murder, of course.
EMILY A double string of pearls with a cashmere sweater set
Mom, she's a young girl. Think of something young.
To put on her desk at the law firm?
Well not with a $200 pen, she doesn't. Oh, hey, look. These day planners are adorable. You could get her one of those funky erasers with a mermaid on it. She'll love that.
Please be serious, we're shopping for Rory.
No, Mom, I'm shopping for Rory. You're shopping for your imaginary granddaughter, Barbara Hutton.
I want to get her something nice.
I know you do, but you're not listening to me.
You wanted me to get her a Filofax and a mermaid eraser.
Oh, yes, and there was a T-shirt with a Farrah Fawcett face.
A hero to many who aspire to the perfect feather fluff.
Oh I don't know how to do this. Let's just go.
Oh, no, no. Come on, Mom. You do know how to do this. Think pudding.
Come on. You asked for my help. You're reaching out. A little -- not a lot -- don't get freaked. But, Mom -- pudding.
Why do you keep saying pudding?
Listen, just look around and pick up something she might like.
Doesn't look like something you could buy at a car wash?
Six dollars more than a car wash.
Twelve dollars is not a present.
Twelve dollars is a perfect present, Mom. She'll love that.
Can I at least get her the pashmina also?
(Cut to Luke's. Lorelai walks in with a garment bag. She looks around the diner and takes a seat at the counter.
All right. You'll have to entertain me until she arrives. OK, Burger Boy, dance.
Just looking for something to shut you up.
You better be nice to me or I'm not inviting you to Rory Gilmore's birthday celebration this Saturday night.
You don't have to ask me, you know.
I know. But I would like you to come.
(Rory walks in with her head down.
Wow. Nice face you got on there.
I've now used the word 'sucks' so much that it's lost all meaning to me.
Well maybe this will cheer you up.
(Lorelai unzips the garment bag and pulls out a dress.

Listen, you. So I'm shopping today with your grandmother and it's a whole three hours of "Who are you buying that for, Mom? Have you met Rory?" and then finally I talked and she listened and she wound up getting you something I think you're really going to like.
Yes, really. And of course she insisted on buying us these dresses but I think I can do something with them to make them better.
Wow. I've never seen you so cheery after spending time with Grandma.
Well it's been a long time since we got together and didn't end up fighting. It was refreshing. It wasn't exactly fun but I didn't get that shooting pain in my eye like I usually do.
So I hear you're having a party Saturday.
Yeah. Mom's famous for her blowouts.
The best one was her eighth birthday.
The cops shut down an eight year old's birthday party?
I don't want to hear any more of this.
So, now tell me, why Miss Lemonhead today?
Nothing. I-I'm fine. I just got an A- on a French test that I should have gotten an A on.
Oh, honey, an A- is awesome.
Let me see. Maybe we should really embrace the whole tulle thing. Go totally modern Cinderella. What do you think? It's your birthday.
(Cut to Lorelai tiptoeing into Rory's room. It's the middle of the night.
(Rory wakes up and moves over. Lorelai gets into bed with her.
I can't believe how fast you're growing up.
Trust me, it's fast. What do you think of your life so far?
I'd like that whole humidity thing to go away.
All right. I'll work on that.
Oh, yeah. You walk into Denny's before 5, you've got yourself a discount.
So you know what I think?
I think you're a great, cool kid, and the best friend a girl could have.
And it's so hard to believe that at exactly this time many moons ago, I was lying in exactly the same position --
Only I had a huge, fat stomach and big fat ankles and I was swearing like a sailor --
On leave -- right! And there I was --
And while some have called it the most meaningful experience of your life, to me it was something more akin to doing the splits on a crate of dynamite.
I wonder if the Waltons ever did this.
And I was screaming and swearing and being surrounded as I was by a hundred prominent doctors, I just assumed there was an actual use for the cup of ice chips they gave me.
But pelting the nurses sure was fun.
Shh. I'm getting to the part where he sees your head. So there I was...
(Cut to Rory and Lane entering Luke's.
You should not have to go to school today.
(Rory and Lane go to the counter.
Jeez. Every day you have a test. When do you have time to learn anything to be tested on?
Since when is there a right table?
Since the coffee cake I baked for you and the stupid balloons I blew up are at that table, over there.
You blew up balloons for me?
I count to three, it's gone.
(Lane and Rory move over to the decorated table.
Yeah, I'm just...I'm getting old, Lane.
You seem a little quiet this morning.

I'm just dreading this whole night. I mean, it's bad enough that I have to see these stupid kids from Chilton every day. But tonight? On my birthday? I've never even talked to most of them. I mean, I've only been going to this school for a couple months. God, they're gonna think I am the biggest freak and I need my grandma to get people to come to my party.
Well what did Lorelai say when you told her?
Oh, the pudding. Right, I forgot about the pudding.

My grandmother served us pudding the other night and then she went shopping with my mom and they didn't fight. I don't know, I mean, they never get along, and now suddenly they're getting along, and I knew that if I told Mom about the invites she'd wig out and call Grandma and that would be the end of the pudding.
You know you can buy pudding.
I can stand it for one night.
(Dean walks into the diner. He looks over at Rory as he shuts the door then goes to the counter
(Dean looks at Rory while he's waiting for his coffee.
(Dean mouths "happy birthday" as he leaves. Rory smiles to herself.
No, not there. In the living room. Why are you touching that? Why are you touching that? Well don't. I want those six inches apart! Get a ruler.
(Richard comes in trying to fix his tie.
I hope the Larsons are coming tonight.
Richard, no business. This is your granddaughter's party.
Five minutes of shop talk isn't going to spoil the evening.
If I ever heard you keep your shop talk down to five minutes, I'd drop dead.
In fact I could drop dead and you wouldn't stop talking business. You'd just step right over my body to get to the speakerphone.
(Doorbell rings. Lorelai and Rory come in.
Jeez, Mom. Leave some servants for the rest of the neighborhood.
There she is -- the birthday girl.
Wow, you really went all out, huh?
EMILY Well I wanted everything to be perfect. What do you think
I think Edith Wharton would have been proud, and busy taking notes.
(Lorelai hands a garment bag to Rory.
Where's the one I bought you?
I thought there was more of it.
Gee, Mom, the place looks great.
Did you turn Rory's into a hat?
You're drinking white wine tonight? No Scotch?
(to a guest) Excuse me. I'm going to sit over there with my daughter.
(Rory is sitting alone until Lorelai joins her and hands her a drink.
