When do you have time to watch General Hospital?
OK, let's get back to the point. What do you think about the whole Liz/Lucky kissing thing?
I think they're actors being paid to play a part so it's nice that they're living up to their obligations.
Look, can we finish this very meaningful conversation later? I promised Lane I'd get right back.
(Rory leaves quickly. Luke comes back to the table.
I'm not gonna say you look concerned.
I'm not gonna talk about how good you'd look dressed like one of the guys from 'The Crucible.'
(Lorelai goes to the market and sees Dean working. She hides in an aisle and watches him bag groceries. Luke comes in, spots Lorelai, and walks up behind her.
(startled) Oh, God! What are you doing?
What is wrong with you today?
Rory had her first kiss and that guy did it.
Oh look at him. Look how smug he is.
He's bagging groceries. It's hard to be smug bagging groceries.
Oh look how he just handled those lemons.
He threw them in the bag. Not tossed them or placed them but threw them like they were nothing to him.
OK. We need to get you out of here.
No. That' Lothario over there has wormed his way into my daughter's heart and mouth and for that he must die!
You're not going to kill the bag boy.
It's double coupon day. You'll bring down the town.
(Luke drags Lorelai out of the store.
OK, OK. I'm out. Stop pushing me.
What are you thinking spying on that kid like that?
I don't know. I just wanted to see him. I mean I've seen him already but that was before he was --
There's nothing you can do about that.
OK, Mr. Reality, break into somebody's else's house.
Why didn't Rory tell me about the kiss?
Maybe she didn't know you'd take it so well.
'Cause all the talk up until now has been so normal.
He kind of looks like Christopher.
The hair, the build, something about the eyes. He reminds me of Christopher.
You're going to quote Freud to me? 'Cause I'll push you in front of a moving car. This talk was going so well.
You and Rory are a lot alike. It's not surprising you would have similar tastes in men.
I guess. But why? Why didn't she tell me? We tell each other everything.
But we tell each other everything else. But this she keeps a secret. It's 'cause it's a guy thing.
Well that's not good. I have to make her understand that I'm OK with the guy thing. 'Cause not talking about guys and our personal lives -- that's me and my mom. That is not me and Rory.
Are you OK with the guy thing?

She just -- she thinks I'll disapprove, right? Well I won't. I will show her that I think this is great. Once she sees that I think this is great, everything will be back to normal between us, right? Right -- OK, good.
So you passed the need for an actual person to talk to several minutes ago.
Oh, yeah. Before the gelato stand.
(Cut to Lorelai's house. Lorelai is sitting on the couch. She gets up and looks out the window then runs back to the couch when she sees Rory is home.
Oh, hey, no big deal. There's Chinese in the fridge.
(Lorelai follows Rory into the kitchen and stands behind her as Rory opens the fridge.
He can spell and read. How long have you known?
Since this morning. You didn't think you were gonna be able to keep it a secret did you? You were making out in the market.
We weren't making out. It was just one kiss.
Yeah, well by the time that gets to Miss Patty's it's a scene from 9 1/2 Weeks.
You've known all this time? At Luke's? Here?
Now, funny, I was going to say the same thing to you.
No? No lecture about kissing a boy?
Why? Did you do it wrong?
I didn't love the way I found out, but you're getting older. These things are bound to happen occasionally. Actually I think it's great.
You're completely weirded out by this aren't you?
No. You're crazy. I'm perfectly fine with it.
You don't seem fine. You seem the complete opposite of fine.
Well you're projecting that on me because you don't want to think that I'm fine when I am, as I have said, fine.
(Cut to Lorelai and Rory walking down the street.
OK, we have to be really quick, 'cause the video store's gonna close, so stick to our list. No impulse buying like toothpaste or soap.
(Lorelai starts to go into the market. Rory stops at the door.
Hey, I think we have enough stuff to eat at home.
Really...where do you live? 'Cause the home I left this morning had nothing.
Well we're ordering pizza. That's enough.
Are you crazy? You can't watch Willy Wonka without massive amounts of junk food! It's not right. I won't allow it. We're going in.
I'm gonna have to meet him eventually.
I'm going to be so cool in there you will mistake me for Shaft.
No kissing noises. No stories from my childhood. No referring to Chicago as Chitown. No James Dean jokes. No father with a shotgun stares. No Nancy Walker impressions.
I really and truly promise. Now can we please go to the market?
All right. Well maybe he's on a break.
Yeah. Yeah, maybe he's on a break.
OK, good. So we can shop.

Mmm...and jelly beans and chocolate kisses. Cookie dough we have at home. Peanut butter. Ooh, do you think they have that thing that's like a sugar stick on one side but then you dip it in the sugar on the other side then you eat it?
We are going to be so sick. It's amazing that we still function. There he is.
Boy, he's tall. That must have been some back-bender, that kiss.
Make sure you warm up next time.
Sorry. Done now. He's got great eyes! You got to love a guy with great eyes.
Think we can get him to turn around?
Oh, you girls having another movie night?
Yeah...It's Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory.
Oh, that's nice. Isn't that the one with Gene Hackman?
Um, Dean, this is my mom, Lorelai. Mom, this is Dean.
Oh, wow. It's expensive to slowly rot your insides isn't it? Here you go.
(taking the bag from Dean) Thank you.
So, Dean, nice meeting you. Hope to see you again.
I said nothing embarrassing, nothing stupid.
See, even a little information in your hands is dangerous.
Mom, the video store closes in ten minutes.
Well you run to the video store and I'll go get coffe.
Go, go, go. I'll meet you at Luke's.
(Rory runs off. Dean comes out of the market.
Hey, you forgot your Red Vines.
Oh, wow! You totally saved the night. Thanks.
Hey, what are you doing tonight?
Me? Uh, well, I don't know.
Well, do you want to come over? We're ordering pizza. We've got a movie. The neighborhood's got a pool going to see who falls into a sugar coma first. I'm the favorite. It might be fun.
Oh, it's totally casual. I'm sure Rory would love it.
Let me give you our address.
That's OK. I know where you live.
Of course you do. So see you tonight.
(Dean goes back in. Rory walks back to Lorelai.
Score! You know, on the one hand I'm glad it was in but on the other hand what kind of world do we live in where no one has rented Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory?
Well thank God for us. Oh, hey, I invited your friend.
Yeah, I told him what we were doing tonight and he was totally into it so -- Why are you looking at me like that?
You invited Dean? To our house?
Because we haven't even been out on a date by ourselves yet. My first date with Dean is going to be with my mother? Are -- What is wrong with you?
I'm sorry. I thought you would be happy about this.
In what universe would I be happy? This isn't Amish country. Girls and boys usually date alone.
I don't think of it as a date. I thought of it more as a hanging out kind of session.
Well I don't want our first hanging out session to be with my mother either.
Like there's supposed to be another word after it.
I can't believe you did this. I'm so humiliated.
You're totally overreacting. I invited him to a movie and pizza, not to Niagra Falls.
He's the boy that I like.
I know. I looked for one that you hated but it was really short notice.
And now he's forced to come over and sit with me and my mother and eat crap and watch a movie?
Well I just invited a friend of yours to hang out. What's the big deal? I mean what if Lane had done it?
You're not Lane. You're my mother. You inviting him over is like Grandma inviting a guy you liked over.
You're comparing me to my mother?
I'm Emily Gilmore? My, how the mighty have fallen.
I wasn't trying to humiliate you.
If I was Emily Gilmore I'd be trying to humiliate you.

Look, I'm sorry, OK? I screwed up. I was trying to -- Look, I'll go, I'll uninvite him. I'll tell him that it's cancelled on account of I just found out I'm my mother and I have to go into intensive therapy right now.
No, you can't uninvite him. He'll think I totally wigged out or something.
Well then I'll just disappear and you guys can be alone.
Oh, and have it look like my mom arranged a date for me? No!
It won't be so bad, OK? Just pizza and a movie and hanging out. I promise you won't feel like your mother is there.
OK. You might, however, feel like my mother is there.
(Cut to Rory's bedroom. Rory is wearing a bathrobe and has clothes spread out all over the bed. Lorelai comes in.
Hey. This is good. Add some cold cream and some curlers and let him know what he'll be coming home to every night.

This was supposed to be a simple night. Watch movie, eat junk, go to bed feeling sick. End of story. Now I'm supposed to look pretty and girly, which is completely impossible because I'm gross and I have nothing to wear.
OK. Uh...let's see. We'll do this and...
(Lorelai looks over the clothes for a minute.
All right This says 'hello, I'm hip and cute but also relaxed since this is something I just threw on even though it looks fantastic on me.'
I've been staring at that top for twenty minutes. It was just a top. You walked in and in three seconds, it's an outfit.
It comes from years of experiencing fashion brain freeze like the one you just had.
This whole guy thing. I mean I've watched you when you talk to a man. You have a comeback for everything, you make him laugh, you smile right --
And then you do the little hair flip.
Oh, twirl. It's a hair twirl.
And then you walk away and he just stands there, amazed, like he can't believe what just happened.
That's because I just stole his wallet.
I'll never be able to do that. Trig, I can do. But boys and dating? Forget it. I'm a total spaz.

Listen, the talking part, you just get used to. The hair twirl I can teach you. And the leaving him amazed part -- with your brain and killer blue eyes I'm not worried. You'll do fine. Just give yourself a little time to get there.
Plenty. Come on. Dab on some lip gloss, clear but fruity. Maybe a little mascara. Wear your hair down and your attitude high.
You're like a crazy Elsa Klensch.
Oh, thank you! Come on now, hustle. We got a man coming over.
(Cut to the living room. The table is full of junk food. Lorelai and Rory are sitting on the couch.
What time did you tell him to get here?
Maybe something happened. Maybe he's not coming.
Maybe he's just late, Miss German train.
(Lorelai goes to the window and looks out.
(Rory joins Lorelai at the window. Dean is standing in the yard next door talking to Babette. Morey is leaning out the window.
There used be a great club there called -- what was it called baby?
Oh, yeah--Mr. Kelly's. You ever go there?
Oh, he sure does. That's all we ever hear about, right?. Jazz, jazz. Jazz, jazz, jazz. Hey.
Hey, sugar. We were just getting to know your young man, here.
Yeah, I see that. So, Dean, um, would you mind going inside and helping Rory out? There's a struggle with a pickle jar lid that I think she's about to lose.
Oh it was nice talking to you, Dean.
And that Chuck Heston chin of his. Is he Rory's boyfriend?
That's not what I heard. Kissing at the market. Gives a whole new meaning to tasting day.
OK. I got to get back inside and shower. So I'll talk to you guys later.
Yeah, have a good evening. And don't forget to invite us to the wedding. Oh won't their kids be gorgeous!
I'm sorry I'm late. I got here like a half hour ago.
We'd believe you if you said you got here three hours ago.
(They all stand there for a minute.
So, Dean, how do you like it here in Stars Hollow?
I like it. It's quiet, but nice. I like all the trees everywhere.

Yeah, the trees are something. When Rory was little, she found out that one was called a Weeping Willow so she spent hours trying to cheer it up. You know, like telling it jokes and -- No, I'm sorry that was me. (silence) Would you like a tour of the house?
OK. So this is the living room where we do our living and, um, upstairs is my room and the good bathroom. And the...kitchen is right through here. You ever heard a fridge yodel before?

script.character: Lorelai: (whispers) you're welcome. (normal voice) well you have your basics
script.text: microwave for popcorn, stove for storing shoes, refrigerator, which is completely worthless.
Oh, I'll get that. Rory, you take over as tour guide. Make sure and show him the emergency exits.
(Rory hovers in the doorway while Dean looks around her room. He picks up a CD.
Wow. Very clean. How much does it suck that they use 'Pink Moon' in a Volkswagen commercial?
I mean you look like you're glued to the door there.
No -- I'm just, uh, observing my room from a new perspective. You know, I hardly ever stand here. It's really making me rethink my throw pillows.
Would you like me to get out of here?
No, I'm fine with you looking around.
(Dean picks up a stuffed chicken and laughs.
Or, you know, at least I was.
We do not need dessert, Sookie.
Oh, everybody needs dessert. So, where is Rory?
Dean? Oh, that's right, yeah, Dean is here.
Yeah, right. OK. You need to go now.
Please. I just want one little peek.
(stalling) OK, fine, so, uh, how are you? How are you doing? How you doing? Are you --
(Lorelai opens the door to let Sookie out. The pizza delivery guy is standing on the other side
Hey, Joe. What do I owe ya?
What did you get on your pizza? Did you ask for extra sauce? Because I always ask for extra sauce because sometimes --
Sookie, she's already freaked out that I invited him here. If she thinks I'm parading him around in front of all my friends, she'll kill me.
(from her room) Mom, is that the pizza?
Yeah. (to Sookie) OK, bye. Now go.
(Lorelai ushers Sookie --with the pizza-- out the door just as Rory and Dean come in.
Just bringing in the pizza. Hi, I'm Sookie. I'm a friend of Lorela's.
Hi. Nice to meet you, Dean. I mean, not that I knew you were Dean. But you do look like a Dean. Doesn't he look like a Dean?
Yeah. Of all the people in this room he looks most like a Dean. Bye Sookie. Have fun!
Oh, thanks. Great. The coffee table's fine.
(whispers) I did not invite her here.
(whispers) Why didn't you just set up a camera and broadcast it over the internet?
(whispers) Because I don't think that big.
Thank God there's good pizza here.
Oh, yeah. Now we didn't know what kind you liked so we just got everything.
(Time lapse. They are all seated on the floor eating popcorn.
Yes I can. Oh that's bad isn't it?
No, uh, most girls don't eat. It's good you eat.
Let's talk about something besides my eating habits, shall we?
My mom has a thing for the Oompa Loompas.
I don't think finding them amusing constitutes a thing.
No, but having a recurring dream about marrying one does.
Don't even get me started on your Prince Charming crush, OK? At least my obsessions are alive. You have a thing for a cartoon.
It was a long time ago. And not the Cinderella one, the Sleeping Beauty one.
So, come on, Dean, tell us some of your embarrassing secrets.
Well, I have no embarrassing secrets.
The theme from Ice Castles makes you cry.
Oh I've got one. At the end of The Way We Were, you wanted Robert Redford to dump his wife and kid for Barbra Streisand.
I've never seen The Way We Were.
What are you waiting for? Heartache, laughter --
I'll have to experience that sometime.
So, uh, at what point does the outsider get to suggest a movie for movie night?
That depends. What movie are you thinking of?
You'll never get that past Lorelai.
She had a bad reaction to Magnolia. She sat there screaming for three hours 'I want my life back!' and then we got kicked out of the theater. It was actually a pretty entertaining day.
I guess I'll have to come up with a different movie then.
That Oompa Loompa -- right there. You know when he's dancing?
(Lorelai starts coming back to the living room, sees Rory and Dean sitting side by side, and goes back into the kitchen to read a magazine.
(Time lapse. Rory tries to get more comfortable. Dean places a pillow behind her back.
(Rory stares at Dean but turns away when he looks over at her.
What are you doing in here?
Trying to find the best bathing suit for my bust size.
Why? What happened? Did the bag boy try something?
He's sitting in there and he's watching the movie and he's perfect and he smells really good.
He smells really good and he looks amazing and I am stupid. I said 'thank you.'
Whoa, whoa, whoa. You said 'thank you?'
He kissed you again? What is he just out of prison or something?
No, not now. Yesterday. At the store.
Oh, all right. Strike the prison comment. He kissed you and you said 'thank you?'
No, it was stupid. And I don't know what I'm doing here. You're sitting in the kitchen. What kind of chaperone are you?
Me? I'm not trying to be a chaperone. I'm trying to be a girlfriend.
Well switch gears, 'cause I'm freaking out here!
You really like him, don't you?
Well, OK, then. Just calm down.
I just don't want to do or say anything else that's gonna be remotely moronic.
I'm afraid once your heart is involved it all comes out in Moron.
Wait we can't go back in together though because that would be too obvious.
All right. OK. I'll go in first and you go to the bathroom.
OK. Good. Tell him I had to wash my face.
Yes. 'Cause of all the sugar you ate.
(Lorelai sits on the floor beside Dean.
Hi. I'm back. Rory went to wash her face.
(They sit in silence for a minute until Lorelai turns the TV off.
Dean. I don't know exactly how to say this, but, um, this is a very different kind of household you walked into tonight.
(rolling his eyes) Ah...here comes the talk.
How about I talk, you listen? Rory is a smart kid. She's never been much for guys so the fact that she likes you means a lot. I don't believe she'd waste her time with some loser.

Sweetheart, the whole town is watching you. That girl in there is beloved around here. You hurt her, there's not a safe place within a hundred miles for you to hide. This is a very small, weird place you've moved to.
So just know all eyes are on you.
She's not going on your motorcycle.
She's not going on your motorcycle.
Fine, she won't go on my motorcycle.
Curfew will be enforced. You will not detract from her schoolwork, and you're going to start handling those lemons better.
Don't interrupt me when I'm speaking. I reserve the right to change, alter, tweak, or add to this list of rules at any given time without any written notice. Am I clear?
You can lay on all the rules you want and you can have the whole town spy on me and stare at me and chase me through the streets --
Oh I like the chase you through the streets idea.
Well it's gonna be a short chase then isn't it?
I need you not to hate me. If you hate me then I don't have a shot in hell with Rory.
Yeah but you're her best friend and what you think means everything to her and you know that.
I wanna like you. 'Cause Rory likes you.
I want to and I usually get what I want.
She's taking a long time on her face.
(Cut to the front porch. Rory and Dean are leaning against the railing.
Tell your mom thanks for inviting me.
I'm sorry if this was totally weird. I mean with my mom inviting you over and --
Hey, no, it was good. Really.
(Cut to Lorelai's bedroom. She's lying on the bed. Rory comes in and lies down next to her.
I don't know. What did you say to him when I went to the bathroom?
Yes there is. Come on, tell me.
Nothing. I just really wanted you to tell me about that kiss.
I'm so sorry. I really wanted to, I swear. I just got scared and --
I know. I'm not mad. I just wanted to hear about it. That's all. It's no big deal. It's OK, I'm fine. It's one too many Caramello bars. I'm sorry. You have school, I have work, so time for bed.
I know this is lame and totally after the fact but --
Start from the beginning and you leave anything out you die! Where were you?
OK, I was in the aisle where the ant spray is.
I know, that's what Lane said too. But anyway, so he was working and I go into the store and I sort of walked around and was pretending to shop...
OPEN AT MISS PATTY'S DANCE STUDI
[Townspeople are gathered for a town meeting
This town meeting will come to order.
No one is listening to me.
I can't calm down, I'm being persecuted.
I promise that we hear you.
We've been hearing you for 20 minutes.
Well, excuse me, Andrew, but some of us have businesses to run that don't involve peddling drug paraphernalia to kids.
It was a lava lamp, Taylor.
There is no use for a lava lamp unless you're on drugs.
Now we've already agreed to look into your accusations, let's just move on. . .
[Lorelai, carrying food and drinks, slides into her seat next to Rory.
[whispers] Taylor Doose wants the no-parking zone in front of his store removed. He says his customers are being unfairly ticketed.
[whispers] No, it's just because he wants to park there all day.

I have been mayor of this fine town for a long time. I tend to think of all of you as my children. Unfortunately, sometimes children have to be disciplined. Now I'm going to say something and I'm only gonna say it once. . .we have leash laws, people.
I would like to now move on to something of even greater importance. As you all know, this coming Friday is the anniversary of the legendary Battle of Stars Hollow. [applause]
Penny will be circulating a sign up sheet for those of you who would like to participate in the reenactment of foresaid battle.
All right. It was a frigid November night, some 224 years ago.
The brave Stars Hollow militia stood in wait for the Red Coats.
Tired and hungry, twelve proud men took their positions in the town's square, braving the elements. . .
He's fighting the urge, he's fighting the urge.
. . .and imminent death in their valiant efforts. . .
Oh, for God's Sake, do we have to go through this every damn year!
And the urge wins by a long shot!
I thought we were here to discuss town issues.
It's me, Harry, Luke. You've known me since I was 5 years old.
Oh, Luke, yes. Sit down. Now as I was saying, twelve heroic men assembled with guns drawn ready to meet their maker.
What are you talking about? Twelve guys stood in a row all night.
Twelve guys stood in a row all night waiting for an enemy that never showed. They got stood up. They should've been wearing prom dresses.
I've had just about enough of this.
Five bucks says somebody ends up in a headlock.
Have any of you ever considered the fact that you're glorifying a war we fought so we could keep land that we stole?
If you don't like it here in America, why don't you go stand in line for toilet paper in the USSR!
There is no more USSR, Harry.
A sense of community is so important, isn't it?
It's what made our country great.
. . .that is a known fact, if you're so interested in facts!

[Lorelai wakes up in the middle of the night, walks downstairs to the living room, opens the window, and takes a deep breath. She walks over and pushes play on the answering machine, then brings the answering machine over to the couch as a message plays from Max.

script.character: Max: [on answering machine] lorelai, it's max. . .medina. maaaax medina. and once again we miss each other. it's now 2 o'clock in the afternoon on thursday and i'm in my office grading a paper titled "emily dickinson
script.text: Get a life." Anyhow, as I sit here losing my faith in mankind, I wonder if we're ever gonna actually go on that date we talked about many moons ago. I teach a night class in Stamford twice a week, and when I pass that Stars Hollow sign on the turnpike, I think, out there is a beautiful woman that I someday hope to spend time with. Anyhow, I'm just thinking about you, and I don't know, maybe next week we can find some time. Goodbye Lorelai. . .Gilmore. You knew that. Okay, bye. [Lorelai pushes play again] Lorelai, it's Max. . .Medina. Maaaax Medina.
[Rory comes out of her bedroom and walks toward the living room
[on answering machine]. . .And once again we miss each other. . . [Lorelai stops the message]
Its freezing in here. [she walks over to shut the window]
Wait, close your eyes and breathe. [Rory does] I smell snow.
Ah, it's that time of year.
You know, it's like dogs and high-pitched noises. I think it's something only you can smell.
[Rory sits down next to Lorelai and pulls a blanket over the both of them
Everything's magical when it snows, everything looks pretty. The clothes are great. Coats, scarves, gloves, hats.
Thermal underwear, wool socks, ear flaps.
Do you know that the best things in my life have happened when it snowed?
Your first steps. They all happened when it snowed.
Feet. [pulls the blanket over their feet]
You are mocking your mother, the woman who birthed you.
During a snowstorm, might I add.
So, how soon is it supposed to hit?
You, me, donuts, coffee, standing out in a snowstorm.
So, how many times are you gonna listen to that?
Stop! That's my teacher you're talking about. I have to respect him.
Okay, well, if it makes you feel any better, while he's being sexy, he's also being grammatically correct.
That's okay. It's all fodder for the tell-all. Goodnight.
[Rory walks back to her bedroom. Lorelai pushes play on the answering machine and pulls the blanket over her head
[on answering machine] Lorelai, it's Max. . .Medina. Maaaax Medina. . .
Hey, how is it out there?
It is cold and gray like a fat dead pigeon.
Ah, we'll need to pull out the sleds, people might want to sled. Ooh, and the parkas, we'll need the parkas.
In case anyone wants to hike.
You do know that not everyone finds the idea of being pelted with frozen water appealing.
I know, and how sad for them.
The thrilling sensation of getting lost in a blizzard, of freezing to death in the woods, and having to eat your friend's buttocks to stay alive, that is lost on many people.
I am telling you, five minutes in a snowball fight, we could knock that stick right out of your butt.
Okay, how does this sound? Maple sugar snowflakes on all the pillows.
Make them in the shape of a buttock, get people used to them.
Okay, is that a real suggestion?
Michel, right, okay. Snowflakes it is.
[Sookie goes back to the kitchen. Rory and Lane, dressed in her band uniform, enter the inn.
I just can't believe it. I mean, I sat next to him at practice for months, and then one day I look over and it's Rich. Rich Bloomingfeld.
Where is my chemistry book? I had it at your house yesterday, didn't I?
I'm sorry. I just can't find my book.
Mom, do you know where my. . .
Big scary chemistry book is? Behind the desk.
Oh, thank God. [goes to get the book]
So, is Sookie in the kitchen?
I just met my soul mate.
Right, Rich Bloomingfeld. Does he still wear the Star Trek shirt?
[Sookie is talking to another chef at the stove
Now, remember, you do not take your eyes off this for a minute 'cause the second you do, it will boil and then it's ruined. So, just stand there and stare at it, okay?
Hey kitty cats. Cinnamon buns are over there.
Do you have any of those rocky road cookies that you made yesterday?
I can scrounge some up. Lane, you need a bag?
So, anyhow, Rich has this amazing hair.
Oh my God, it's so perfect. It's thick but it's not too thick, and it's got really good natural wave, so he probably uses way less product than most guys.
Always a plus. Hey, what time is it?
I have to get to the bus stop. Dean's meeting me there.
But I'm trying to talk to you about this.
I know, we'll talk on the way.
[Sookie walks over and hands Rory a bag of cookies

Hey, sweets. I have a locksmith coming to the house today like five-ish, and I don't know how long it'll take, so will you tell Grandma and Grandpa that I'm gonna be late, and that I'm having Satan's baby. You pick the order.
I'll relay the time message but I'm leaving the rest up to you.
What is this? You hate rocky road cookies.
I do not. [takes the bag back.]
Oh, I'm sorry. That must be my other daughter, Schmory.
Wait a minute. I know who likes rocky road cookies.
She's bringing baked goods to a boy. Wow, serious!
[in high voice] Here Dean, these cookies are for you, 'cause you're keen.
Love, love, love, Dean, Dean, Dean!
[singing] Cookies for the love and the Dean and the cookies for the love and the Dean and the cookies for the love and the . . .
[singing] Dean and the love and the Dean and the love and the Dean and the love. . .
Okay, we can stop, she's gone now.
[singing] The cookies for the Dean and the Rory and the cookies for the love with the Dean. . .
[Rory and Lane walk toward the bus stop

Tradition is a trap, it allows people to stick their head in the sand. Everything in the past was so quaint, so charming. Times were simpler. Kids didn't have sex. Neighbors knew each other. It's a freaking fairy tale. Things sucked then, too. It just sucked without indoor plumbing.

The bell rang? I was late for chem lab?
You ever sorry that you didn't?

[Rory is staring out the window, bored. Emily is on the couch. Richard is on the phone

I'll be right back. [Rory goes upstairs and gets a photo album out of the bedroom. She brings it back to the table.] I found this in Mom's room.
Oh, my goodness. I haven't seen that in years.
Yes. There were 12 petticoats underneath it. We got it in London, remember, Richard?
She looks like a little princess

You're welcome. That I didn't really think this thing out, and, uh, I usually think this kind of thing out, so I'm just thinking this thing out.
Inviting a man over to my house.

I mean, I've dated, and, uh, you know, dated, but, um, I've just never dated. . . here in our house.

'Cause I can do weird and funny. Lorelai, I've been enjoying the hell out of myself tonight, and I think you are, too.

Oh, that's The Cure. I have to go back in there.

I'll be back as fast as humanly possible.

Yes, it's perfect. Then you can run your hands though anybody's hair you want and they'll pay you for it.

Bring guys home. I mean, if you like someone you should feel comfortable doing that.

(Emily, Rory, and Lorelai are having dinner.

(shows Lorelai the cover) It was a spotted owl.

How can you do that when you don't bother to read the newsletter?

Well apparently they won't, dear. That's why they need the donations in the first place.
(to Rory) So, you have a formal coming up?

Mom, I said nothing, OK? Rory's disdain of formals is totally her own. Let's just drop it, please.
(They both go back to their food.

That's true. However, not really, since you've never actually been to one you're basing all your dance opinions on one midnight viewing of Sixteen Candles.
So you should have a decent reason for hating something before you really decide you hate it.

Trust me, I'll hate it. It'll be stuffy and boring, the music will suck and since none of the kids at school like me, I'll be stuck in the back listening to 98° watching Tristin and Paris argue over which one of them gets to make me miserable first.

OK. Or it'll be all sparkly and exciting and you'll be standing on the dance floor listening to Tom Waits with some great-looking guy staring at you so hard that you don't even realize that Paris and Tristin have just been eaten by bears.
I don't know -- maybe the guy who hangs out in our trees all day waiting for you to come home?

Listen, I know you are not Miss Party Girl, and I love you for that, but sometimes I wonder -- do you not join in because you really don't want to or because you're too shy? If the reason you don't want to go is because you really don't want to go and not because you are in any way afraid, then this is the last time I'll mention it, I promise.
Oh yeah. We could get some great shoes and some new earrings. You could get your hair done.

Look, have you had the talk yet?
Yes, Lane, babies come from the stork.
"We've been dating a few weeks no. Where do we stand? What are we to each other? If another girls asks you out, do you feel free to go?"
How is it that you know so much about this?
Those who can, do. Those who can't, teach.
(They look in the window of the market and see Dean with a customer.
(Rory starts to leave. Lane stops her.
No. No, you have to do this now.
Because I have to go home soon and my mom threw out our TV when she caught me watching V.I.P. So I'm bored and I need some entertainment.
(takes a deep breath) OK. Here I go.
Good luck! Oh, and Rory, remember to enunciate. I'm reading lips out here.
(Rory goes into the market, leaving Lane with her face plastered to the window. Rory walks up to Dean.
Yeah. I just have to put the new green bean shipment on the shelves. You want to help?
Yeah, sure. I, uh, I love stocking beans.
So do you work on Saturdays? I forget.
Well it depends. Sometimes I come in if I don't have any plans. Why?
No reason. See, there's this thing at my school on Saturday. Well it's not really at my school, it's kind of given by my school .
Well it's this thing where you go and they play music and you're supposed to get all dressed up and do some kind of dance and then there's chicken.

Well I don't know if there's chicken. But at these kinds of things they often serve chicken because it's probably cheaper and people eat it, so the logic behind the chicken choice really isn't that bad.
And it's not like I'm dying to go or anything, but it is a new school and being a part of the social activities is really important at Chilton.
So are you asking me to go to the dance with you?
No. Yes. I mean, if you wanted to go, I would go too.
Well that would probably be good since it's your school.
Right. So do you want to go?
I've actually never gone to a dance before.
Yeah. And it's just not the way I ever wanted to spend my time. I mean, I'm not a big joiner.
OK, fair enough. More beans please.
You want to go, don't you?
No. I don't. I have no desire to go at all. I was just thinking out loud, that's all.
So, uh, what would I have to wear?
To this dance. What would I have to wear?
No, really whatever you're comfortable in is fine.
Some sort of pants would be nice.
But you could probably get away with a coat and no tie.
(Rory goes back outside where Lane is waiting.
(Cut to Lorelai making a dress on a dressmaker's dummy. While she's bending down, she falls over, bringing the dummy down on top of her.
(Lorelai gets up and goes to answer the door.
Oh, God bless. I've been working so hard to finish Rory's dress I haven't been to get out.
I know. Rory's dress made a pass at me and I think I pulled something getting up.
Here, sit, sit sit. Hey, you know what, I've got an Ace bandage in my bag. I'm not sure how we can wrap it but maybe we can do something kind of creative and --
(Sookie pulls bottles of pills out of her purse.
OK, I've got Percodan, Vicodin, Darvocet, and, uh...Take this one. It's a muscle relaxer. Very mild, I promise.
OK. I've got to go. You sure you're going to be OK?
I'm fine, Mom, I just stubbed my toe.
Maybe you should get rid of some of that clutter in your living room.
Ah, you know, I've seen the light. Everything goes. What else have you got?
I want to talk about Rory's dance. It's just killing me that she's not going.
It may seem frivolous and silly to her now but belive me, these are the kind of experiences you regret missing later.
And regret can make you bitter. Do you want Rory to be bitter?
What, Mom? She can make some cash off of it. Become a crazy Oscar Levant kind of celebrity, go on talk shows, heckle Regis.
I wish you would take this seriously.
Mom, Rory is going to the dance.
I'm making her dress right now.
Well, so she'll look really ugly and people will point and throw rocks.
Why don't you let me buy her a dress?
Mom, you were thrilled five seconds ago, remember?
You're not using the curtains are you?
Just one more thing. Take a picture of Rory for me, will you please?
On the stairs. And one by the front door. And one as she's getting ready, you know, putting her hair up, putting her makeup on?
OK, do you want one when she's shaving her legs? You know, one leg up in the tub, waving the disposable razor in the air?
This is a once in a lifetime event. You get to be there and I don't.
(Lorelai lies down on the floor, trying to get comfortable.
I figure if I got enough pictures I could at least line them up in chronological order and pretend I was there.
Maybe bind them together, make a flipbook out of them.
Mom, would you like to come over on Saturday and see Rory go to the dance?
Why, what a nice idea, I'd love that, thank you. I'll see you at 7.
(Emily hangs up the phone. Lorelai sighs.
(Tristin walks up to the table where Paris is selling tickets to the Chilton Winter Formal.
Nah, what am I thinking? You wouldn't be free this close to the dance.
(He hands her some money and she hands him the tickets.
Yeah, a quarter of an inch.
(Tristin walks down the hall to where Rory is reading while waiting in line to buy tickets.
And she's reading again. How novel.
Did you get the novel thing? Because...
The guy's supposed to buy the tickets.
Really. Does Susan Faludi know about this?
Unless of course there is no guy.

Well, what can I say? I like 'em cheap. Sloppy too -- bald spot, beer gut, you know, and the pants that kind of slip down in the back, giving you that good plumber shot. That sends me through the roof.
How many languages can you say 'none of your business' in.
Does he go to this school?
Uh-huh. Well, look, OK, I'll confess something to you. I don't have a date.
Well I hear Squeaky Fromme is up for parole soon. You should keep a good thought.
Well I actually thought you'd like to go with me.
You did not because you are not stupid.
Slimy and weasely, yes, but stupid, no. You'd have to be stupid to think that, given our history, I would ever, barring a piano or a safe falling on my head, want to go anywhere with you, ever.
I'll send her a condolence card.
Yeah. Well at least she won't be buying her own ticket.
(Tristin walks down the hall. Rory is next in line.
He was totally nice to you and you couldn't be a bigger jerk.
You like Tristin so much, you go out with him.
What am I, your Versateller? Wait for change. (yells at the boy sitting next to her) I need change! Now! (to Rory) There's no way you're going with someone better than Tristin.
You probably don't even have a date. You're probably going to come down with some very rare form of flu that only hits losers on dance night.
You know what? I don't want my change. Money makes people shallow.
I've got your change. Hey! Hey! If you think I'm keepig this dollar, I'm not!
(Saturday night. Lorelai is sitting on the couch reading a magazine.
You're 16. You have skin like a baby's ass. There's nothing to primp.
(Rory comes into the room wearing her dress for the dance.
Wow. Someone hit you with a pretty stick.
This dress is amazing. You outdid yourself.
It's beautiful, babe, you look beautiful. Come here.
Yes. Hm. I think my favorite part is the shoes.
I'll just throw them on on my way out
No, you should put them on now and let your feet get really numb.
Go get me the hair spray.
(Rory runs to get her shoes. The doorbell rings.
I got extra hot sauce and a couple of extra burritos to put in the fridge in case you get hungry later.
You take such good care of me.
(gasps) Oh my God! You're a movie star! I'm serious. Oh my -- At some point tonight, walk down a flight of stairs. Movie stars always walk down staircases.
OK, come on, let me spray while you try to figure out what she just said.
You, don't move. I got it.
(Sookie points the bottle in the wrong direction and ends up spraying her eyes instead of Rory's hair.
Yeah, sweetie, hand that to your mother, and my eyelashes are all stuck together.
Honey, are you sure you're alright?
(to Rory) Shield the tacos. OK, ready?
(Rory puts the tacos under the table and covers her eyes. Lorelai sprays her hair.
OK, that will be good for six slow dances, four medium ones, one lambada, but if you plan on doing any moshing I suggest another coat.
Rory, sweetie, is this soap by the sink in the silver bottle?
We're in here? That's how you answer the door?
Well I was all out of Saran Wrap.
I don't even want to figure that one out. I just want to see my granddaughter. Where is she?
Oh, perfect. I want to be all ready for the big entrance. How's the light in here? Never mind. I'll just take one with the flash and one without to make sure we got it right.
Wow, Mom, look at you. You'd think Anne Taylor was having a sale or something.
(Emily, armed with a camera, gets into position.
OK, Rory, come in here please.
(Rory comes into the living room wearing a kitchen towel as a bib and eating a taco.
(to Lorelai) She has lived with you too long.
Honey, lose the bib and the taco, put your shoes on, come back out, and let Grandma take the pretty picture.
I walked. (to the staircase) It was nice to see you again, Mrs. Gilmore, or at least make out your shape.
Call in fifteen minutes or I'm sending out a search party.
(to the wall) And you call me if I can come over and help you up the stairs or something.
Why would you need help up the stairs?
No reason. Rory, let's go, your public awaits!
I have a little back spasm, that's it. It's no big deal.
I don't know, Mom, just a normal one.
There is nothing normal about a back spasm. The very fact that it has the word spasm in it means it's not normal.
Alright, here she is, Mom, get your camera moving.
What? Oh, my, you're gorgeous. Oh! Smile!
I'm so glad you decided to buy her a dress.
(Lorelai and Rory exchange a look. A car horn sounds outside.
Hey, come here. Have an amazing time.
(Rory kisses Lorelai and Emily and then Rory runs for the door.
I'll chronicle the whole evening for you, I promise. Bye, Grandma.
You do not go running out the door when a boy honks.
It certainly is not fine. This is not a drive through. She's not fried chicken.
But I told him to honk and I'd meet him out there. We agreed.

I don't care what you told him. If he wants to take you out, he will walk up to this door, and know, and say 'good evening,' and come inside for a moment like any civilized human being would know to do.
Now, Mom, this is silly, I have met him already.
We will wait until he comes to the door.
He doesn't know he's supposed to.
(Rory sighs and crosses her arms. They wait in silence. A minute or so later, Dean honks again.
He's not a very bright boy, is he?
(The doorbell rings. Rory starts to run to the door.
Don't rush. A lady never rushes.
Hey, uh, I thought I was supposed to honk.
Young man, come in here please.
Hey, Dean, meet my mother, Emily Post.
Great rap session. Alright, you guys are out of here. Have fun.
What do you know about this boy?
I know that Rory likes him and that his parole officer has high hopes for his rehabilitation.
It is a crazy question, Mom, because if I had knowledge of him being a drinker, he would not be with Rory now.
Mom, please relax. Dean is a good kid. Rory's gonna have a great time. You got your pictures and tomorrow I will call you and give you all the details.
What are you going to do?
Well you certainly can't be left alone.
You can barely move. You've been sitting on that couch since I got here.
That's because this is a right comfy couch.
No, no, Mom, you really don't have to do that.
I'm not leaving my daughter stranded on the couch. What if you need to get to the bathroom?
I don't go anymore, Mom. I gave it up cold turkey.
No, Mom...Look -- I can stand, OK?
See? I'm up. OK, see? I'm fine.
Move. If you're fine, than move.
I can move. This is me moving. (nothing happens) Any second now the moving will begin. (nothing happens) Rats.
I'll go start some tea. Please tell me you have something besides Lipton.
(muttering to herself) Oh, a stroke would be so good right about now.
(Cut to Rory and Dean. They are in the car on the way to the dance.
Maybe we should just forget about this
I mean, it's just a dance. What's the big deal?
And these kids at my school -- awful. Have you seen The Outsiders?
Just call me Ponyboy. I heard this place is beautiful though -- old and historic.
Maybe we could just go in for a minute.
I don't know. Why can't I decide? This is stupid. What do you think?
I think that you look amazing.
Maybe just a couple minutes won't hurt.
(Cut to Lorela and Emily. Emily is on the phone. Lorelai is still on the couch.
Yes, Marta. Just make sure everything's locked up before you leave. (pause) No, I won't be home tonight.
So, Mom, you really, really don't have to do this.
Don't be silly. I couldn't possibly leave you alone like this.
I'm trying to find the candlesticks I bought you.
The Baccarat candlesticks I bought you last year for Christmas. I assumed you stuffed them in the back of the closet somewhere.
Uh, well, no, I did not stuff them in the back of the closet.
Well then where are they? I don't see them out.
(hesitantly) Well, see, we didn't actually have a...big use for the crystal candlesticks so I kind of...exchanged them.
It's a lamp with a bunch of monkeys on it.
Baccarat candlesticks for a moneky lamp?
They're really, really happy monkeys, Mom.
Where is this lamp? I want to see it.
It's right there on the desk.
(Emily walks over to the lamp and looks closely at it.
Oh my God! They're holding coconuts and leering!
You traded my lovely gift for for a semi-pornographic leering monkey lamp? How could you?

This is not just about the bad breeding of returning a gift. This goes right to the heart of the question of taste. You were given something of substance and you cast it off for a ridiculous, slightly sinister barroom decoration. Explain this to me, Lorelai.
(As her mother rants, Lorelai's smile turns to a frown. She sinks lower on the couch and covers herself with a blanket.
(Cut to the Chilton dance. Rory and Dean are standing near the back of the room.
Well it's a very good room.
I commend the person that suggested this very location.
So, we could just get our picture taken and leave.
Or we could dance a little first.
(Madeline and Louise are sitting at a table at the dance.
We have to wait for Paris anyway.
Rory Gilmore. God, she's got good hair.
He's not of the manor born, that's for sure. Let's go.
(Madeline and Louise saunter over to Rory and Dean.
So, should we dance or should we sit first?
Rory...you came. Oh, great dress. Who's it by?
No, my mom made it for me.
So you traveling with a bodyguard now?
Oh, no. This is my -- this is Dean. Dean, this is Louise and Madeline.
You know, my whole family is really tall. The men, mostly. What are you -- 6'1", 6'2"?
What, does he get like a prize if he guesses?
One kind of soup, actually. It's green, lumpy.
Actually, she can't make soup either.
(Dean moves behind Rory and puts his arms around her waist.
What do you think? Too tall?
Although the saddle shoes make it kind of difficult.
Well I'll just have to stoop then.
(Madeline follows Louise. A slow song starts as Rory turns in Dean's arms.
(Rory and Dean are about to dance when Paris and her date walk up to them.
Hi, I'm Rory. This is Dean.
OK, so, this dancing thing is not something I want you to get used to or comment on.
Hey, if I kiss you is a nun gonna come out here and boot me out of here
(Tristin is watching Rory and Dean kissing.
Mom, I think somebody already ate that.
That is a mashed banana on toast.
I used to make this for you all the time when you were a little girl.
Yes, whenever you got sick I made this.
Are you sure it wasn't the other way around?
I'll just take it back to the kitchen
No, Mom, I said I want it.
Are you sure? Because I can throw it away.
You can't possibly be comfortable like that.
Mother, please, this is the first position in 24 hours that that has not made me crazy.
Please don't make me eat this.
Well, Sookie left me a burrito in the fridge.
I'll go warm it up for you.
Oh. Fine. I'll just go get it then.
OK, uh, I need something to drink. Do you want some punch?
(Jacob approaches Rory when Dean goes to get their punch.
Are you having a good time?
It's OK. So, was that your boyfriend?
Oh. I don't know. I'm not sure.
We've only been going out a little while, so...
So, there's still a little room to play?
Maybe I could get your number.
I'm sorry, aren't you here with Paris?
So maybe you shouldn't be over here asking me for my number then.
Paris is your cousin? You're related?
Jacob, it's been very nice to meet you. I hope you have a lovely evening.
(Cut to Lorelai and Emily watching TV.
Oh look -- Barbara Stanwyck. I just love Barbara Stanwyck.
She had that wonderful voice -- that husky, deep voice. I just love that voice.
You know Mom, you have kind of a Barbara Stanwycky voice.
I mean it. You could have gotten Fred McMurray to off Dad if you'd really wanted to.
Oh you do enjoy teasing me, don't you?
You know, Rory looked so lovely tonight.
I just can't get over how she's grown up into that little woman who walked out of here.
I know. (pause) You know what, Mom?
Well, let me get this out of your way. You really don't remember me making this for you when you were sick?
Well I did and you loved it.
You know what? Let me give it a try.
It's even more disgusting than I thought it was going to be.
(Emily takes a bite and makes a face.
Oh my God, it's horrible! What on earth was I thinking?
So, uh, you want to maybe go?
You're bored. I'm sorry. Yeah, let's go, right away.
I'm not bored. I thought, you know, there's still a little time left, maybe we could get a cup of coffee somewhere, hang out a little, talk a walk. You know, just us.
No, you stay. I'll get the coats.
(After Dean leaves, Paris walks up to Rory sitting at the table and leans into her.
So. How many people have you told? Four? Five? Everybody?
You know that Jacob is my cousin and now you finally have all the ammunition to pay me back, right?
(The people nearby are starting to stare.
I don't want to pay you back. I just want to get awy from you.

(voice gets increasingly louder) Now you can just go all over the school and just tell everybody that Paris Geller couldn't get a date to the dance. That she had no one and since she couldn't just not come, she had to get her mother to ask her cousin Jacob to take and then she had to give him gas money to make him do it. Go ahead! Tell them!
I don't have to. You just did.
(Paris and Rory look around. Everyone has stopped dancing and is listening to them. Paris walks away.
Yeah. I wouldn't get quite so excited about it.
Oh, why, did she say something mean?
Actually, no, Rory doesn't use words like that. I embellished a little.
Oh so you're the big strong protector? Little princess needs a protector?
Nothing. Just don't like your girlfriend, that's all.
Really? Doesn't look that way to me.
I don't really care how it looks to you.
Hey. You got in my path, not the other way around.
(Dean starts to walk away. Tristin steps in his way.
Get out of my way Dristan.
Nothing. Just getting to know your boyfriend here.
It's going really well, don't you think?
Oh yeah. We're just about to build a clubhouse.
OK. Well I hate to break up the party, but we should go.
Oh, why? Little girl's got to be home?
No, I think you two make a very cute couple. Is your horse and buggy parked outside? Got to get home for the barn raising?
(Dean and Rory start to walk away. Tristin steps in front of Rory. Dean shoves Tristin. People around them stop dancing and start watching the two guys.
What the hell do you think you're doing?
OK, you will not push me again.
Are you seriously trying to act tough? You're wearing a tie for God's sake.
I'm not fighting you. It'd be like fighting an accountant. I'll call you when I need my taxes done.
(Tristin lunges for Dean. It takes a few other boys and a man to separate them.
You don't want to fight me Tristin!
'Cause I'll kill you, idiot! Come on, Rory, let's go.
(As Rory and Dean walk away, Tristin breaks free from the people holding him back. Dean turns around and gets in his face.
You will not come near her. Ever again.
Did you really bring your cousin?
(Cut to Lorelai's house. Lorelai is sleeping on the couch. Emily is still watching TV. She reaches over for the remote control.
I'll tell you how it ends.
(Emily tucks Lorelai's hair behind her ear and covers her with a blanket.
(Emily sits in a chair to read.
(Cut to Rory and Dean walking outdoors in Stars Hollow.
I seriously don't know what got into him.
He has a thing for you.
No he doesn't. It's just a game to him or something.
He has a thing for you.
He does nothing but insult me and make me miserable.
He has a thing for you.
I don't know how I feel about this whole situation.
I don't know...having my boyfriend defend my honor. It's weird.
No! I just meant boyfriend in the sense that the whole defending me thing was very boyfriendy, but only in the broadest sense of the word, which doesn't even apply at all here.
I didn't mean that you're my boyfriend.
I don't think you're my boyfriend.
In the broadest sense of the word way?
No, in the real, 'hi this is Dean, my boyfriend' kind of way.
Well I am if you want me to be.
I'm feeling pretty good about this decision.
(The door to Miss Patty's dance studio is open.
I guess Miss Patty forgot to lock up.
I've never really seen in here before.
(They're inside, looking at the pictures on the walls.
Are all these women really Miss Patty?
Yep. She said she's done everything there is to do in show business except set fire to the hoop the dog jumps through.
I'll get it. God, this weighs a ton. What do you have in here?
I don't know. A lipstick, five dollar bill. Gum, hair spray, a book.
You brought a book to the dance?
You thought there'd be a lot of downtime?
No. I just take a book with me everywhere. It's just habit.
So, uh, what are you reading?
(reading) 'There's little in taking or giving. There's little in water or wine. This living, this living, this living, Was never a project of mine.' Cheery.
(They settle into a comfortable chair together.
Thank you for tonight. It was perfect.
(They kiss then continue to look at the book.
(Time lapse. They're still asleep. Miss Patty and a large group of women come into the dance studio.
OK, ladies. Grab your yoga mats.
I don't think I'll ever get warm again.
(The women gather around Rory and Dean.
(shocked) Oh, my goodness! It's Lorelai's girl!
She's over here. Asleep with the bag boy from the market.
What are we supposed to do?
Rory, honey. It's Miss Patty. Rory? Rory, what are you doing here?
Yes. have you been here all night?
Oh my God! We fell asleep. How could we have fallen asleep?
Calm down, I'll explain it to your mom.
(hysterical) Where's my purse? Where's my purse?
I'm going with you. We'll explain. It'll be OK.
No you can't come with me. You shouldn't be anywhere near my house right now.
I know. I just have to get home.
Look, please, please let me come with you.
(Rory runs down the street towards home. Dean lets her go.
(Cut to Lorelai's house. Emily is shaking Lorelai awake.
Lorelai! Get up. Now. Right now!

script.character: Emily: i sat in that chair all night and i dozed off for one second and the next thing i know it's 5

script.text: She's not there. Aren't you listening?
Where's the phone? Call the police.
What are you doing? Call the police! Call the police!
I'm looking for the phone. What do you think I'm doing?
Why don't you ever clean up around here? This is an emergency and you can't even find the phone. What if there was a fire? What if Rory was choking?
I know that and your yelling is not helping me!
(They continue looking for the phone. It rings
Rory? (pause) Oh, Patty. (pause) What? (pause) OK. (pause) Thanks. (pause) No, than you so much. (pause) OK Bye-bye. (hangs up) Rory's OK.
She and Dean were at Miss Patty's.
Um, it's a dance studio. That was Patty. She said that she found them asleep and woke them up and Rory's on her way home.
In what state were they found in?
She didn't say, OK. Let's just try to be calm until we know what happened.
What do you mean 'until we know what happened'? We know what happened.
Lorelai Gilmore, I've watched you do a lot of stupid things in your life and I have held my tongue.
But I will not stand by and let you allow that girl to ruin her life.
She spent the night out with that boy, the one you let her run off to that dance with.
Mom, so help me God, I will not get into this with you.
She's doing the same thing you did.
She's gonna ruin everything just like you did.
No she's not! No she's not! No she's not! Rory is a good kid, Mom! She's not me.
What kind of mother are you to allow this to happen to her?
Oh, I don't know, Mom. What kind of mother were you?
You're going to lose her. You're going to lose her just like I lost you.

I am not going to lose her. Do you hear me? Even if I hadn't gotten pregnant, you still would have lost me. I had nothing in that house. I had no life. I had no air. You strangled me. I do not strangle Rory.

Oh you're so perfect and I was so horrible. I put you in good schools. I gave you the best of everything. I made sure you had the finest opportunities. And I am so tired of hearing about how you were suffocated and I was so controlling. Well if I was so controlling why couldn't I control you running around getting pregnant and throwing your life away.

You will not come into my house and tell me I threw my life away. Look around, Mom. This is a life. It has a little color in it so it may look a little unfamiliar to you, but it's a life. And if I hadn't gotten pregnant I wouldn't have Rory.
(Rory sneaks in the front door and hides by the stairs.
You know that's not what I meant.

Maybe I was some horrible uncontrollable child like you say, but Rory isn't. She's smart and careful and I trust her and she's gonna be fine and if you can't accept that or believe it, then I don't want you in this house!
(Emily walks out and slams the door. Rory creeps into the kitchen.
Mom, thank you for saying all those --
What were you thinking? Staying out all night! Are you insane?
I'm sorry. It was an accident.
You're talking to the queen of staying out all night. I invented the concept! This is no accident! You can't do this! Period.
Do you have any idea what it's like to wake up with my mother here and find out that you never came home?
So all this is about Grandma being here.
No, it's about the feeling of complete terror when your kid isn't in her bed in the morning.
And then it's about a whole different kind of terror when you find out that she spent the night with some guy.
I didn't spend the night with him. We fell asleep.
You are going on the pill.
What happened to all that stuff you said to Grandma What happened to trusting me? Where did all that go?
I think it's back on Patty's yoga mats.

This is crap! You know I didn't do anything. You know this is an accident. You're just mad because I screwed up and I did it in front of Grandma and she nailed you for it. Well I'm sorry. I'm sorry that I screwed up and I'm sorry that you got yelled at, but I didn't do anything and you know it!
(Rory goes into her room and slams the door. Lorelai sits at the kitchen table and cries.

People please pay attention. Now, I want my before Mary over here, and my after Mary over here. Wise men, shepherd line up for the processional. I only have half a donkey? I need the rest of the donkey!
[Kirk standing on stool while Lorelai hemming
Ok, be quiet now. [looks at Rory]
Um, Taylor, the baby Jesus is missing an arm again.
I was just getting it out of the trunk and -
Let me see that. Oh for Pete’s sake! [to everyone] Ok listen up! The arm is missing! I repeat the arm is missing!
Maybe it’s just time to get a new baby Jesus, you know, one that’s a boy.
It’s a doll, no one can tell.
This has been the baby Jesus in every Christmas pageant since 1965. Were you here in 1965?
Find the arm [Rory looks at Lorelai]
You stuck me once. There’s nothing to say you won’t do it again.
Ok you know what? You’re done.
