(to Luke) Hey, we just found the doggy version of you.
Do not let these two anywhere near a dog. They can barely feed themselves.
Shut up you! We'd be excellent pet owners, thank you.
We could get him a pretty bowl...
..cause this 'Buttercup' thing really has got to go.
Do I need to remind you of Skippy?
I can't believe you would bring up Skippy.
Every time mom would put her hand in his cage, he'd bit her.
Oh this one laughed - trust me.
So finally she got fed up.
Of being laughed at by a hamster?
So she stopped cleaning it's cage. Instead everyday she would stuff some Kleenex in there.
It was the quilted kind (with a small smile)
So this keeps going on and the cage is just a cage full of Kleenex that moves a little, and the smell? Really good.
So then she takes the cage to the place where we bought him, waits for the sales guy to go behind the desk and dumps it on the counter then bolts.
Look, I know it was bad, but this was a vicious hamster. This was like a Damien hamster with little beady eyes and a big forked tail and...a cape with a...hood...and bye bye Buttercup. Bye Luke.
You did the right thing. (both walking away from the puppies with arms around each other)
Oh (in a whiny tone). I want a pet.
You won't bring me my slippers in the morning.
I might if you had slippers.
Hey watch how you talk to me. Remember what happened to Skippy.
(Cut to Max Medina's apartment. He's cleaning while Lorelai sits on the counter eating out of a pot.
OK. Correct me if I'm wrong.
Twenty minutes ago we were sitting at the dinner table were we not?
There were candles and flowers and plates and knifes and cloth napkins.
I love the little sombrero napkin holders, very ole.
And the whole time we were at said dinner table, you ate two maybe three bites of this amazing dinner I made for you.
And yet, as soon as that dinner's over and I start cleaning up, suddenly that's when you're starving.
What can I say - watching someone work makes me hungry. If I hadn't stopped watching "This Old House" I'd be 500 lbs right now.
In the dish please. Ha ha ha. (as Max puts food into pot.)
So where did you learn to make osso bucco anyway?
Um, from this very old Italian woman...who used to live upstairs...um, s-she had lost her husband a couple of years before and she kinda looked at me as like a son.
So would you like some coffee?
Yes please. (Walks by Max and their faces come very close together)
Hey did you read Rory's paper yet?
Oh and look! It's right on top.
(laughs) Wow, there are some really big words in here. I just hope you have a dictionary with you when you read it.
You know I could just save you the time and uh, put an 'A' on it for you.
Well that really wouldn't be fair to the other students who's mothers aren't here tonight would it?
Yes you're right. (pause) Although, life isn't fair and the sooner those kids learn that the better.
Well I'll take that advise into account.

(giggles). (turns around to look at his books) Wow these are beautiful!. Hm, I never read Proust, I always wanted to. Every now and then, I'm seized with an overwhelming urge to say something like "As Marcel Proust would say.." but of course I have no idea what Marcel Proust would say so I don't even go there. I could do, uh, "As Micheal Crichton would say.." but it's not exactly the same you know.
Oh no! It-it looks so valuable
It's a book. It's meant to be read.
(She takes the book and sits down and starts to read
I'd rather you didn't read it now.

But um, what about (Max kisses her) my required reading (stands up, moving towards the bedroom, between kissing..) But I won't make the cheerleading squad! (kissing) Mr. Medina, is this my extra credit work because Missy just had to take a test!?! (laughing through kisses. Door closes.)
(Cut to Lorelai sneaking in with shoes in hand
Where do you think you're going?
It's one o'clock in the morning.
I know but my watch stopped during a terrible car wreck and I had to save kittens and small children and four baby chicks.
Did you have a nice time?
That's a very big smile for a not bad night. (Lorelai sits on the couch)
Yeah well...Hey he loaned me a book.
You know what it means when a man loans you a book don't you?
(laughs a little) How was your night?
How many times did Dean call.
(laughs) Not an all time high but very respectable. I'm going to bed. You staying here?
Yeah. I'm comfortable. I've got the pillows in a perfect mushed position.
Yeah you just go think about what you've done.

"There's a certain slant of light, winter afternoons that oppresses like the heft of cathedral tunes." That, my friends is the first verse of a poem by Emily Dickenson. Now read some of those tonight, and as you do, consider the fact that Emily Dickenson writes convincingly about passion and about the world in spite of the fact that she lived as a virtual recluse. It'll help you appreciate her mind. (bell rings)
I could listen to him talk about passion all day. Do you think he's dating anyone?
Male teachers are different. They can still be mysterious.
Dumb girls crave smart men. It's that whole Marilyn Monroe - Arthur Miller syndrome.
Whoever he's dating is a loser, who doesn't care that he's a teacher in this ridiculous school making a ridiculous teacher's salary. (to Rory) What are you looking at? (walks away)
Guess someone read the paper today.
I know. Paris' parent's divorce is getting very ugly!
Her dad should've just paid her mom everything she wanted and this whole thing would've been over.
That's what my dad did. (to Rory) Hi!
Is it true Paris' mom had the entire back of her body surgically reconstructed?
Well it doesn't match the front now does it?
It's the best tiny, weird bird I have ever eaten.
Why are you smiling like that?
Well what smile is it Loerlai?
That's your "I've got something on Lorelai" smile.
Rory your mother must be very tired.
I grew up with that smile - I know that smile.
Well, my French final went pretty well.
You can change the subject. I know the smile.
I've used it a few times myself.
So tell me about parent's day?
Parent's day? Next Wednesday? When all the parents are supposed to go to the classes with their children all day long?
The Chilton newsletter came out today!
Lorelai, you're really being silly. There's no evil plan a foot here. I simply brought up a subject I thought we could all talk about.
I'll try another subject - the colour blue is very pleasant isn't it?
Mom not everybody can wait outside the mailbox for the Chilton newsletter to arrive and then instantly memorize the contents in three seconds.
I'd like to weigh in on the blue colour subject please.
You have your priorities far be it from me to question them.
Just because I don't read the newsletter doesn't mean I don't care about my daughter.
Why don't we talk about it next Friday when I've actually read the newsletter. I guarantee it'll be more fun.
We could except for the fact that parents day is next Wednesday.
If we talked about it on Friday then you would've missed it.
It's ok mom, you don't have to be there.
I guess we can talk about how you missed it.
Mom it's not a big deal, you're busy.
Why not? You have to work. I, as you have insinuated, have no life, therefore I will go sit with Rory at parent's day.
I'm not busy, I'm going. I will be there - that's it. End of story ok?
So did you read on page two about the mother/daughter talent show?
Mom I have to go! It's almost 8 o'clock!
(Lorelai running around her room getting ready
Wait! Have you seen my orange suede clip thingy?
(Rory huffs and goes upstairs to help
Did you check in your purse?
(Lorelai looks in the sock drawer and finds it.
Mom come on! Mr. Medina's going to be here any minute!
Ok, just tell me one more thing. Where's the silver dangly bracelet?
Oh...right...Hey can I borrow your silver dangly bracelet?
I'll leave it on the table for you.
(Rory heads for the door and the doorbell rings
Why did the door bell ring?
(Lorelai comes down the stairs while Max listens from outside.
It's 8 o'clock. Who shows up at 8 o'clock for an 8 o'clock date?
I don't know, maybe a Chilton teacher?

script.character: Lorelai: everybody knows that 8 o'clock means 8:20, 8

script.text: Well obviously he was raised in a barn.
I tell you, he's cute but this punctuality thing has knocked 10 points off the dream guy quotient.
Mom what do I do? I'm not even supposed to be here.
Oh wa-wa-wait! You have to get the door.
I'm not supposed to get the door remember, we agreed. I don't get the door when you have a date.

I'm not even supposed to be here. That's the first rule of the 'Gilmore Dating Handbook'. (as Lorelai fiddle with her skirt zipper). Daughter shall be nowhere near house when said man materializes. It's a good rule, it 's been working.
Ok, but he's standing out there and it's cold and my slip is now completely stuck in my skirt zipper and they'll have to bury me like this.
Just this once! (as she runs upstairs)
Can I get you something, I mean we don't really have anything but if you wanted something and we had it, I'd be happy to get it for you.
It's not bad water actually. I mean it's not a funny colour or anything.
We really need to go to the store.
So, uh, what are your plans tonight?
I'm going over to my friend Lane's house.
(Both look upstairs. Max clears his throat.
But the thing is, if things go well, the way I hope they're going, then we might be doing this again.
(laughs) Seeing each other outside of school.
That's ok. I am fine with this whole you and my mom thing.
Well, better go. (gets up to leave)
It's good to talk to you Rory. (standing up)
You too Mr. Medina. (She turns to leave)
why don't you call me Max? Just when we're out of school.
(turning back) I don't think I can do that.
It just sounds wrong - disrespectful. I mean, you're my teacher Mr. Medina, and if I start to think of you as a 'Max' - even as a part-time 'Max', it just seems lit it would get too confusing.
How 'bout then, we'll come up with non-Chilton names for each other. When we're not in school, I'll call you Rebecca.
I look like a Norman to you?
I'm sorry, 'Psycho' was on earlier and it was just the first name that came to mind. I'll think of something else. How about Alfred?
I'm positive, I love it. I might make a legal change.
I hope you and Lane have a good time.
Thanks. Oh, would you give this to my mom for me?
Oh and Norman - have her home by 10.
(Rory's sitting at the counter as Sookie and Jackson enter
I can't believe you won't just sell them to me.
And I can't believe you're being so small minded.
My stuffed fried squash blossoms are extremely popular with the customers.
People come from all over and demand the fried stuffed squash blossoms.
What'll you have sir? Anything that comes with the stuffed fried squash blossoms. That's what I hear day in and day out.
Yes, great, I know, but all I'm asking you is to try stuffing something a little different this time huh? (holds up a zucchini tush)
You want me to serve my customers a genetically engineered vegetable that's named after a butt?
Hey this is an all natural vegetable hybrid that's perfectly safe, completely delicious, and yes it looks a little odd but you can put in on the map!
Fine. You wanna think small, think small. I'm done. (leaves)
(Sookie sighs and sits next to Rory
Jackson invented a new vegetable again?
It's too bad that bowling league didn't work out for him.
(Lorelai enters with skates over her shoulder
They were in that drawer with the roasting pans.
Rory and I have a skating date.
And I'm Tonya Harding. I'm gonna do the whole shoe lace coming untie - nervous break - let me start again act and everything.
(laughing) When was the last time you put those things on?
Oh, you are constantly trying to ruin my fun.
Well...can I just have some coffee please?
I'm gonna clean them and tighten the blades.
Can you make them really shiny?
Maybe add a couple of pompoms.
You get really good service here.
Too much yeast, too little bowl.
(to Rory) So I think I'm just going to go for it and wear the fur-trimmed skating skirt, pride be damned.
Hey, what if we invite Max to go skating with us?
Yeah, I thought maybe he'd want to go.
When did you start calling him Max?
Well the other night he said that I should probably call him something other than Mr. Medina when we're outside of school. Which makes sense, so I'm getting used to saying 'Max'.
W- you don't see him that much outside school.
No, but I probably will since you guys are obsessed with each other.
No. It's ok, I mean of all the guys to have hanging around, he seems like a good choice. I like him.
So what do you think about the skating?
Mr. Medina - I'm sorry, Max? Do you think he'd wanna go?
I don't think he skates. (to Luke) Thanks.
Well maybe we could all do something else together.
Yeah, good. Something else is good. I love something else.
Ok, tea is ready. How are the feet?
I don't know. They stopped talking to me.
What on earth were you thinking?
It's not like riding a bike you know.
So, (sitting at table) what are you up to tonight.
Well, I'm going to do a little line dancing, then run a 10K, then just jump up and down really hard for about an hour.
I don't seem him every night Sookie.
He seems like a great guy.
No, he is. He is a great guy - for someone.
Someone else who is not you although you're the person spending every waking hour with him.
Aha. How long have you been dating?
Two months you've been seeing him right?
Mmm. Just right on schedule that's all.
I have no idea what you're talking about.
This is about the time you start doing you little getaway dance. Two months right on the nose - you're good.
I do not do a dance.
I'm not cha-cha-cha-ing. I'm being practical. Rory is starting to get attached to Max and that's not good.
Oh Rory's getting attached to Max?
Yes and since I've decided that Max is probably not the guy for me, I think it's better that we break it off before she gets hurt.
Uh, can I say something here?
Shake your bon-bon, shake your bon-bon.
Hey, you will not stand there singing Ricky Martin songs to me. This is not a pattern ok? I'm not doing what I always do. This is not the same.
Actually you're right. Usually you don't get so upset and defensive during the cha-cha talk.
(painfully) Ah! (as Sookie pours hot water into foot basin)
You must really like this guy.
When did you become the relationship expert? You haven't been in a relationship in years. (Sookie looks sad as Lorelai realizes what she said). Wow! Zero to jackass in 3.2 seconds.
No it isn't. It's never ever ok for me to talk to you like that. I'm so so sorry. Please honey.
(sighs) I understand - really. You know it's not like I don't want a relationship.
I know. I didn't mean anything by it.
(sighs) It's just - it's hard with my hours. I'm always at the inn, or at the market or at the hospital.
Please - forgive me. Do you wanna...sing some more Ricky Martin to me?
You can you know - I deserver it.
(quietly) 'She's into superstition, black cats and voodoo dolls. (louder) I've got a premonition, that girl's gonna make me fall.' (imitates guitar tunes)
You know I heard that Paris' dad's actually got a second family in Paris.
(Rory rolls her eyes as she walks by.
I enjoyed your paper on Dickenson.
You're welcome (Rory turns to go) Um, Rory?
No, that's it. That's all I wanted to say.
Actually I just wanted to see if Lore- (looks around) if your mom is coming to parent's day.
Cause I'm just trying to get an accurate number of parents who are coming - you know for the cookie count.
(relieved) I hadn't heard from her for a while about it and -
But you should put us down for four.
The Tuesday in the not so distant past.
Toss it. (sits at table) So you remember Paris Geller.
Your very best friend in the whole world?
Her parents are getting a major divorce.
Her dad's like this big wig at a huge pharmaceutical company and they're printing all the sordid details about it in the paper.
Well, it's not the Rich James incident, but Hugh Grant should be feeling pretty good about himself.
If she was anyone else in the entire universe I might feel bad for her.
Actually I kind of do feel bad for her.
That's because you are the nicest kid ever to walk the earth.
The whole school's talking about it. And the weird thing is that the whole dynamics there has changed for me.
Really? How so? (gets up to go towards fridge)
Well, Madeline and Louise, Paris' best friends, they said hello to me the other day.
Really? Like a normal hello? Not like a 'Here's Johnny' kind of hello?
Oh, hey, this is the pizza from mystery Tuesday. That one's completely fine (pointing to the one in the garbage bin.)
You're kidding! It took me forever to read that. I had to renew it 10 times.
The first sentence - I finished the first sentence.
Yeah - it's just - I'm so swamped right now you know, it's the totally wrong time to start reading the longest book known to man. Hey maybe you could give it back to Max for me?
Just bring it with you tomorrow.
I know (she didn't) I'm just - I'm not sure I'm going to be able to make it.
Well I have that thing at the inn and I thought I could get away and now I can't.
The thing at the inn with the flags and the little men and the peanuts - the thing.
Forget it, it's not important - I just don't think I can go.
So, if you could give this book back to Max tomorrow - that would be great.
Why don't you just give it back to him the next time you see him.
Because I'm not sure when that would be and he should have his book. (getting a bit upset)
You see him all the time.
Rory, could you just (drops book on table) give it back to him ok?
Are you breaking up with him?
Well he hasn't heard from you and now you're asking me to give him the book back.
How do you know he hasn't heard from me?
He wanted to know if you were going to Parent's day and then he mentioned that you guys hadn't talked lately.
He shouldn't be asking you about me.
Why are you breaking up with him?
So that's why you're not going tomorrow?
No, I'm not going tomorrow because of the thing at the inn.
That's crap and you know it (upset)

There is no thing at the inn, you're avoiding Mr. Medina and you're trying to lie to me and you promised you would go and - hey, do whatever you want. I don't care, just leave me out of it. And give him the book back yourself. (Rory goes to her room and slams the door.)
Fine I will. (takes the pizza out of garbage.)
Before you go one more step - tell me you like me?
I'll take that as a yes. And I want you to know that I will deal with my issues with Max myself.
To my locker to drop off some of this stuff.
(see Paris and her mother by Paris' locker arguing
At least come to my lit class.
This place is giving me a headache.
You have not being using that cleanser have you? Now Dr. Yanalari prescribed that cleanser for a reason - to cleanse.
Paris with everything I have going on right now the last thing I need to do is face a bunch of bored people who are gossiping about me. I'll see you later at home. Use that cover stick I got you.
I bet I'm looking pretty good to you right now.
Hmm. So what's first? Wait don't tell me.
English lit with Mr. Max Medina.
Ok see I told you not to tell me.
How does first annual mother/daughter ditch day sound?

On Monday we will start a two week of creative writing exercise, but that doesn't mean we stop reading. One of the greatest inspirations of working writers is the writing of other that they admire. Walt Whitman read Homer, Dante, Shakespeare. And the novelist Edna O'Brien has been quoted as saying 'that every writer should read some Proust every day' Now, at this point, normally I would impress the partens by pulling out a copy of Proust's 'Swann's Way' and reading a particularly difficult passage but alas, you're all saved. I have misplaced my copy. (bell rings) Oh that does is - parent's thanks for coming, students - papers on Whitman are due tomorrow and those of you who are just starting tonight - I'll be able to tell.
So you go on ahead ok? I'm going to talk to Max for a second.
Hi - it's nice to see you.
I wanted to give this back to you.
I really liked it. I like the first 20 pages anyway, then I got busy and I can see you really need it so - (tries to give him the book)
Nothing. I just don't think a book whose first sentence is 20 pages long is for me.
I know - I've been meaning to call.
So - here. (tries to give him book again)
Why do you keep on trying to give me the book?
Is there something going on here that I don't know about?
Look, um Rory's out there waiting for me so... (tries to give him book again)
Wa-wait a minute...Oh my God! I cannot believe what an idiot I am.
You're breaking up with me aren't you?
Not only are you breaking up with me, you're doing it really badly.
No, I'm a little disappointed. I would've expected a better dumping from you.
Well I don't. In fact I want as little space as possible. 100 clowns crammed into a Volkswagen. That's the kind of non-space I'm talking about.
It was working pretty good the other night.

Look it is what I've been trying to tell you all along. This is a family. Rory and I, you walked into a family, but you weren't listening and now she's getting attached and I'm afraid she's gonna get hurt.
So you solution to all of this is not to return my calls
It just took me a while to figure things out and it all came clear when I realized how much we could hurt Rory.
Don't you mean how much we could hurt Lorelai?
Hey - I can take care of myself.
I don't understand this. I thought we went through this. W-we decided she could handle it.
Well maybe she can and maybe she can't. I'm not ready to find out.
I'm not going to let you off that easily.
Well there's nothing you can do about it.
What are we in high school? Well I know we are in a high school.
Well, you don't know everything about me.
I guess not, because I would've thought that blaming this all on Rory and giving me these lame apologies was weak, pathetic and beneath you.
I know you did, you're missing me right now aren't you?
Well I didn't raise my hand so don't call on me! I came here to give you this book back, please take it.
I swear to God if you try to give me that book one more time...
(They kiss passionately. Outside the class Paris walks by and sees them kiss
(Gets noisier and noisier as Paris walks from table to table talking to people. Tristin walks by Rory and makes a 'kiss' sound to her. Paris walks up to Rory.
Oh, everyone's just talking about the mom that Mr. Medina was seen kissing just now.
And the weird thing is - she looks a lot like your mom.
Your mom - Mr. Medina, mouths open. I saw them. How's the coleslaw? Good? (walks away)
Hey, did you save me some jello?
What? (follows Rory out) Rory?! Hey where are you gong?
Mr. Medina, just now, were you kissing him?
What the hell is wrong with you?
You said you were breaking up with him.
I know I told you to be nice to him but this was a little extreme don't you think?
Paris saw you! It's all over the school!!
Oh God - oh Rory, I'm so sorry. I really am. See this is exactly why I didn't want to date him.
You didn't want to date him so you wouldn't come to my school and kiss him and humiliate me?
Because I'm human, because I screwed up. I'm sorry.
If you like him so much then why are you breaking up with him?
Look, I broke the rules when I brought him into our lives and I realize now that that was a very bad idea.

Why?! Because we are standing in this stairwell yelling at each other that's why! Because it's affecting you, it's seeping into your life and that is the whole reason I made these rules in the first place. Is-is to protect you!
You know what, maybe it was a good idea that you hid your personal life from me when I was a kid but I'm not a kid anymore.
No, you're right. You're a 40 year old divorcee - my mistake.
Ugh! I can't believe you're blaming this on me!
You made up these stupid rules years ago about the way the Gilmore women would run their lives and now you're sticking to them even though they're crazy!

Oh hey my crazy, stupid rules are the reason we're doing so good in our lives. They're the reason you grew up the way you did, the reason you're even in this school and the reason you're going to go to Harvard so don't you dismiss my rules.
Fine! Great! Well, maybe it's time for the rules to change!
Yes, well that's for me to figure out, not you!
Great! Fine! Well could you figure it out before French class because I'd rather you didn't start making out with Mrs. Collins.
Hey no promises until I see what she looks like!
Look, let's just refrain from fighting in front of the grandmother ok?
The last thing I need tonight is a confrontation with my mother
Hi mom, boy the roads were a mess out there tonight. (entering)
I have to talk to your mother, please go upstairs.
(walks into living room) Lorelai come here!
Gee mom, did I do something wrong?
I try to understand you, I truly do. But sometimes your behaviour baffles me beyond belief.
Is that intended as a rhetorical question or - ?
Rory goes to school in that place, she has a reputation to protect. You're her mother.
You're supposed to shield her from shame not cause it.
Kissing a teacher...in a classroom...on parent's day!!!
Well...they wanted us to get more involved with the school.
No but you are if you think I'm discussing this with you.
When I heard I almost fainted.
I have friends Lorelai. Headmaster Charleston's wife for one.
The entire school is talking about it. And what do I say, how do I defend this?
A mistake? A mistake? Is that what you call it a mistake?
Well I tried to call it 'Al' but it would only answer to 'mistake'.

A mistake is when you throw out your credit card bill - a mistake is when you forget to RSVP to a dinner party - a mistake is when the gardeners miss trash day and the barrels are full for a week. This my girl, was not a mistake! Do you even know this man?
Ah, no, this is the first time I'd seen him and I don't know, there was just something about the way he held the chalk and -
This is not the time for your jokes.
Yes I knew him. I've been dating him.
Why on earth would you date Rory's teacher?
When it affects my granddaughter it becomes my business.
I don't want to talk about this with you!
I just want to know what you were thinking. What was the reasoning? How on earth did you justify it to yourself?
Max is a great guy. An amazing guy! He's smart, he's sweet (teary) he cooks.
So you decided to kiss him in your daughter's school.
No, I decided to breakup with him in my daughter's school and the kissing part just happened.
You always let your emotions get in the way. That's the problem with you Lorelai - you don't think.
Oh so what are you telling me. That this was all worth it because he was the love of you life, that this was the man for you.
I don't know. He might have been. Excuse me (leaves room)
(Rory sitting at a table. Paris, Louise and Madeline walk up behind her.
See, I told you he wouldn't date a teacher.
I wish my mom would sleep with my teacher, it would make midterms a lot easier.
(Rory slams her book closed, stands up and turns to face them
Madeline, Louise, would you excuse us for a minute?
You're not going to kiss me are you? (smiling)

You've just spent the past two weeks with all of your family's private problems printed in the newspaper for everyone to read and talk about. I saw how you walked around here! I saw how much you hated it. And then you turn around and pull something like this? Doesn't that seem crazy to you? Do you have any idea how many people you've hurt? Forget me and my mom, what about Mr. Medina? He likes you, he encourages you. He hold up your papers and tells the class how great you are. And then you turn around and spread stories about him. (pause). Whatever, forget it. You have no idea what I'm talking about. (grabs her stuff and starts to leave)
Well I'd take some dance lessons cause the way you express yourself needs a little work.
I...probably shouldn't have told people what I saw.
I'm sorry...things have been...well...not good lately.
I just didn't want them talking about me anymore, that's all.
You know, i-if you want to talk -
Oh that I know. But if you ever do...want to talk about -
I will, if I want to.
Bye. (Paris starts to leave and turns around)
I'm not holding my breath. (sighs and leaves)
(Jackson drops a box of squash blossoms on the counter
There - squash blossoms. All large enough for you to stuff and fry up and serve to the desensitize masses who just want what they know. Hurrah!! Mediocrity wins again!!

You know what, I'm not even gonna charge you for these. I am not going to profit off the death of creativity. I would rather starve myself than know that my food was paid for by the lowered expectations of the American public. (starts to leave)
Would you like to go to dinner sometimes...with me?
Hey Mister, wanna buy a really nice copy of Proust?
So that parent's day is fun.
Oh, it was a big hit this year (both laugh a little)
Look, the other day, we were going skating, and Rory said "Why don't we invite Max to come along with us" and that was a little weird for me.
She's never really referred to anyone I've dated by their first name before. I always kept her out of that part of my life, so it was like "the mustache guy", "the earring guy", "the peg leg guy".
Oh so you have a thing for pirates.

Lane is not allowed to date boys unless we have approved them. She knows that, she knows our rules and she broke them. That is unacceptable.
Ok, yes, you’re right. But teenagers sometimes slip up.
I don’t care what teenagers do, I care what Lane does.
You know, it doesn’t always work to just lock a kid up and throw away the key.
I didn’t throw away the key, it’s in the kitchen.

[taken aback] Ok, well, I was talking symbolically...but alright, I’m with you now. Look when I was a teenager, my parents tried to keep me locked up. They tried to force me to become what they had in mind, and now I’m not talking exactly about Lane here, but in my case, it really didn’t work.
You blame your parents for getting pregnant.

No, I just think sometimes if I’d had a little more space or someone to listen to me, things might have turned out different. Now I got lucky, because having Rory - totally the best thing that could have happened. But let’s be honest, I certainly don’t want Rory to turn out like me.
I don’t want Lane to turn out like you either.
Now I believe that’s the first thing that you and I have ever agreed on.
I just want Lane to be safe.
I just want Rory to be safe. So, I’m gonna go now. Hey, I think you are doing a great job with Lane. She’s a really great kid. I just wanted to put my two cents in because that’s what I do, so. Bye.
[walks out of room and breaks a vase on the way out

I know it is. Of course if she tells me the story of how Jackson cultivates his own mealworms to help fertilize his plants one more time, I’m going to Romeo and Juliet them both.

Give me your cell phone quick.
Where are you going? I wanna hear.
I do not want to incur the wrath of Luke.
I’m standing in the yard! I’m standing in the yard!
Oh my God, she let you out!
I can go as far as the sign.

Oh yeah, fine. The dating world of 16 year olds - very exciting stuff.
You know, I had a good time the other night - with the cards.
Yeah, if fact you rushed out of here before I had a chance to -
Maybe we could do it again sometime.
Oh yeah, well, I-I would like that.
Lane’s allowed outside for 15 minutes. I’m gonna go over and stand across the street and yell at her. [ rushes to the door]
Do you still want you burger?
[Looks at Luke, then drinks her coffee.
[Lorelai looking through her closet. Rory laying on her bed
I’m sorry, I’m looking but there is nothing in here.

I do. There’s nothing to give up.

It’s got rhinestones and zebra stripes on it.
Ok, I’ve had this since I was 17

I don’t understand why I have to up root my happy family of clothing anyway.

Ok, get out of the way.
[Blocking her closet] What are you doing?
Step away from the closet please. [pushes her aside]
Oh! Oh, this is so unfair! Oh no, no, no. [Rory takes a section out of her closet] Not that whole chunk! Well, just - ok take that, that’s ugly. Just that one...no...uh.

[walking to the dresser] Ok, now all of this goes [pointing to clothes in her arms] I want you to come over here to this dresser, open up the top drawer and take out everything that you’d be embarrassed to be wearing during a car accident. Meet me downstairs. [leaves. Over her shoulder] Move!
A big furry purple thing that could be either a hat, a toilet paper cover or some kind of dirty hand puppet.
Clothes, rags and some old pots and pans [holding up respective bag at a time]
Kitchenware can go in the kitchen and the clothes can go right over there.
Ok. [heads for the kitchen after putting clothes down]
Somewhere in the state of Connecticut, yes there are crackers.
Me please. Um, kittens in the toilet poster? [holds up poster]
[from the kitchen] Ah! There a man in my kitchen, somebody call the constable.
[coming into the living room. Lorelai following] You’re mom’s a fruitcake.
Good bye Rory, I wish you luck - [looks at Lorelai] with everything.
Ok, so rummage sale’s Sunday, today is Tuesday. At this rate, we are going to be sleeping in the yard by Thursday. We have got to start getting some of this stuff out of the living room.
I have a full set of dishes.
Oh, um, dishes in the kitchen please.

The butter dish has a small chip in it.

I have here in my hand, as requested by Ms. Lorelai Gilmore, four fabulous tickets to the Bangles at the Pastorella theater on Saturday!
Are these good seats? These look like good seats.
I can’t believe you got me my tickets! Well, how did you score these?

Yes. They were so thrilled with the volcano wedding cake that they wanted to do something nice for me and since Mr. Birnbaum runs a ticket agency and I knew you were dying to so, so I asked him if he could...
Hey Sookie, if you got four tickets and you and mom go, then that means...
Hmm, one for you and one for Lane! [Lane and Sookie hug] Oh, chickadee!
This is gonna be a very special night. And you know what a very, very special night deserves?
[pulls out a hot pink dress] A new outfit!

As I mentioned yesterday, we will be holding a debate next week. Your subject ‘Did Charles I receive a fair trial’ The pros will represent the parliament who deemed they had sovereignty and the cons will represent the monarch and try and prove that the charge against him was not legal. What is fascinating Mr. Dugray? [catching him looking at Rory]
My notes - my notes are fascinating Ms. Caldecott.

Yes they are fascinating Mr. Dugray. As I was saying, the pro and con teams will each have two minutes and 30 seconds for introductions, six minutes to debate, three minutes for conclusions and five minutes for questions from the audience. The winner shall be decided by a hand count from the rest of the class. Does that sound like fun Mr. Dugray? [again, he’s looking at Rory]
The debate. Does it sound like fun?
It does, doesn’t it Mr. Dugray?
Oh, it absolutely does Ms. Caldecott.
More fun than staring at Miss Gilmore’s ear?

Yeah, I think so too. Ok, any questions? Good, I’ll assign your teams. [Pointing] You, you, you, you - con. You, you, you, you, - pro. [in background for next two lines] You, you, you, you - con. You, you, you -
[whispers] Well I think she... [looking at Louise and Rory]
I wasn’t sure who you pointed to just now.

[Paris, Louise, Madeline and Rory standing around

CUT TO RORY AND LANE WALKING TO KIM HOUS

After church we think about what we heard in church.

CUT TO LUKE’S WITH A RUMMAGE SALE SIGN IN THE WINDO

[Lorelai walks in with a black and brown polka dot cowboy hat on
Margaret Atworthy just dropped off three boxes of city council pot holders and begged me to take her grandson. People are getting crazy man. What?

The one on your head, Annie Oakley.
As nice as it is that you’re single handedly trying to rebuild the bridge, you have got to stop buying up other people’s junk.

Mom don’t worry about it. They’ll come in, they’ll make a face, they’ll say something snotty, we’ll study, they’ll leave. I’m just looking forward to this whole day being over, then I can concentrate on the concert.

She was to Luke. I thought they were going to get married.
The rumour is that Starts Hollow was too small for her. She wanted to live somewhere more exciting.
Mm. You know Luke. He lived here all his life. He wouldn’t even go away for college. I think we’re going to bury him in that diner.
Yeah. Ok, well I am done here. I’m gonna stop by the inn for a while and then I am gonna go home and I’m gonna change for the show tonight.
We’ll need the actual quotes so learn them by heart.
Note cards look sloppy. We will know our information.
But the other teams will use note cards.
And the other team will lose.
Bye girls, Rory, see you tonight!
We’ve got tickets to see the Bangles at the Pastorella theatre.
It’s gonna be great actually and the seats are amazing.
You’re going to a concert with your mom?
I cannot imagine doing anything like that with my mom.
Actually we do stuff like this all the time.
Hey, how old is your mom anyways?
So that means she had you when she was...
16. She had her when she was 16. We’ve done the math, can we just ‘ooh’ and ‘aah’ about this quickly and get back to work?
We’re all 16 ok. Everybody in this room is 16.
Paris is right. We should work.
I can’t imaging having a baby at 16.
Well then keep your knees shut.
Do you think your mom is sorry she got pregnant so young?
I didn’t meant that. I just meant that...
I mean, I don’t think she would recommend it but I think she’s happy with how things turned out.
Ok, just checking. Hey, I’m starving, is it pizza time yet?
Ok, one with cheese, one without. Cokes?
I find your mother completely fascinating.
It’s almost more like having a big sister.
And you like her don’t you?
[from the kitchen] Rory come in here a sec!
Hey, how’s it going in there?
Well we’ve basically gotten no work down at all. Paris is having a meltdown, which by the way is always fun.
And, I don’t know, we’ve just been talking.
Well, I think you’re actually making some friends here.
Let’s not get ahead of ourselves. They’ve basically just moved off the plan to dump the pig’s blood on me at the prom, that’s all.
Talking, chatting, no work being done - there’s friend potential going on.
Maybe - with Louise and Madeline at least.
Two out or three formerly psychotic enemies - not bad. There [handing Rory a plate]- pop-tart appetizers to tide you over till the pizza comes.
Hey, I have kind of a crazy idea.
Those are never comforting words coming from you.
Now, we have four tickets to the show tonight.
What if I give them to you? You take them.
Well, it just seems like you guys have kind of a bonding thing going on in there, it might be fun.
No, no you and I have already bonded. In fact, if we bond any further, we will be permanently fused together.
You’ve been talking about this concert since you heard about it.
Sookie and I can buy cheap seats when we get there.
These tickets are 9th row aisle - dream seats.

Look, you don’t have to do this, but I just think you have three years of Chilton ahead of you and it might be nice to have some friendly type people to talk to there. And I don’t know, you guys seem to be getting along, it might be good. And I totally don’t mind, I just want to see the show, I don’t care from what seat.
Oh ladies! [taking plate and going into the living room] Hey what are you guys doing tonight?
Well we have these really great tickets to see the Bangles at the Pastorella theater and Rory thought you might like to come along.
Yeah - I mean if you guys want to.
He made it [Louise and Madeline look at bracelet Dean made for her]
And you wear it all the time right?
Ok here [offers tickets but pulls them back] Ah! With these tickets you are about to enter sacred space, you will be treading on hallowed ground, you will be walking like an Egyptian.

Take’em. Oh you’re going to have a great time. The Bangles are the best! They were my favorite band in high school. I almost named you Susanna. The day I found out you had no musical talent at all was the saddest day of my life.
Well you say that now. Here, ok, these are probably located - Hi! [to usher]
Can you tell me where these seats are?
Uh, those are right in here.
Oh good, girls...ok, here’s the deal. Take the tickets, go to your seats, have the night of a lifetime - Bangle it up. The second the concert is over, meet us outside in front of the theater got it?
You’re welcome. [to Sookie] Ok, let’s go make our noses bleed.
I have never sat this close to a stage before. In fact, I’ve never even really been to a concert before so I could be sitting at the back and say the same thing.
[checking out the cute guys in the row behind them] Yes they are.
[to Paris] What are they looking at?
One guess. [Rory looks behind them at the guys]
Check it out, we’ve got fans [seeing Rory]
Was I right? [as Rory turns back]
And before it’s dark, they’ll have every picnic basket that’s in Jelly Stone park.
[Pan to Sookie and Lorelai climbing stairs

[laughing] You mean a flame thrower? [to guy] Do you get it? A flame thrower because it’s so far.

I’m just curious, was she pretty?

I mean, like was she a Catherine Zeta-Jones kind of pretty or a Michelle Pfiffer-y pretty or -
She was an Elle MacPherson kind of pretty.

And you don’t think that’s crazy?
Oh I do think that’s crazy?
Oh my God! He is so gorgeous.
Listen, there’s a massive party going on right around the corner.
Jess and Sean, we’ve been talking to them this whole time, they’re extremely cool.
We have to meet my mom after the show.

Of going out into a strange city with two guys I don’t know? Yeah.

That you’re a very good little girl. [gets up and leaves]

Can I ask you a question?

Ok. When is not a jerk?

Yes...and he has things in his life that are hard. His parents - not so great. We have that in common.
In the 6th grade - on a dare.

I know he’s flirting with me to get to you, but at least he’s flirting with me.

Madeline and Louise met these guys and they -

I leave the house with four girls, I’m coming home with four girls. [knocks on a door] Hi, I’m looking for a couple of college boys, who might live here or have friends who live here.
I don’t talk to anyone. People annoy me. [closes door]
[coming up to Sookie listening at a door] What?
She found him with the blonde again.

[knocks] Hello? [dog barks] Aah! Let’s go follow your mother.
I wonder if I was missing if my mom would come looking for me like that.
Yeah, or at least she’d send somebody.
[Lorelai knocks on another door. There’s music playing
Mom, that’s one of the guys.
Thanks. Hi, could you move please? [enters]
Ms. Gilmore. Put the cups down, let’s move.

Yeah, see those two idiots over there? They’re 16 - underage and I bet you’re not. I also bet those big fancy party cups aren’t holding lemonade. I am not even going to begin to tell you how completely insane it is to take off with anyone you don’t know, or drink things that you don’t know what’s in them, or act like you have a clue when you don’t, but so help me God if you ever pull a stunt like this again, it will not be around my kid! Do you understand me?

I cannot believe I missed it.

I’m gonna get a soda, anybody want anything?
Yes, the night of my 14th birthday back so I can right the green-hot-pant-roller-disco outfit wrong.

Careful, Richard. That canary you ate is going to spoil your dinner.
Oh, your mother and I have just secured a place on Martha's Vineyard.
I thought you lost your old place.
We did. But this afternoon we found out that Arthur Roundtree had died.
So we got on the phone and snatched that place up.
Oh, it's a fine piece of property.
Much better than our usual place.
The both of you are going directly to hell, I hope you know that.
Well, at least we'll be well rested.
I am so thrilled about this.
The two of you must come up for the weekend. It is so lovely. Rory would just love it.
Can we go for a weekend?
We'll see how much Valium Auntie Sookie can lend Mommy, OK?
The only drawback of course, is that we had to rent the place furnished, and Arthur had dreadful taste. Remember the library, Richard?
Pink and green! Horrible. Just horrible.
Well he's dead now so he got his.
Joan and Melissa Rivers here think I'm being morbid.
Rory, what's new in your life?
Nothing. I was just teasing her.
Nothing. Rory just dressed up in a cute apron the other day and so I was teasing her about it.
Why did you get dressed up in an apron?
(pause) Well. We've decided to give up on that pesky Harvard dream and focus on something more realistic. Mom, Dad, Rory's decided to become a maid, just like I was.
Is that funny? Did she think that was funny?
What would have posessed you to say such a thing?
Why don't you tell them about your bird? That seems like a safe subject.
Yeah, it's for school. Each of us have to follow a chick through its entire growth process. Everything has to be logged. Eating habits, sleeping habits.
She's a better bird for it.
Rory said that Luke found her.
Paying me back for the apron thing?
Did the bird get loose at Luke's diner?
The bird got loose at home.
So, Grandpa, when's your next trip?
I think there's a nice addition of cervantes in it for you.
What was Luke doing at your house?
Oh, look, there's no ice. I'll get some.
He was helping me find the bird, Mom.
And how did he know that the bird was missing? What, was he strolling by your house and he heard your plaintive cries for help?
Or the helpless cheep of a chick in trouble?
I called him, Mom. OK? I called him and asked him to come over and help me look for the bird. OK?
It seems like this man is always around when you're in trouble.
Do we have to discuss this?
EMILY Lorelai, I'm getting a little tired of being lied to

This man was at Rory's birthday party, he came to the hospital with you, he's the male lead in every story you tell, you go to the diner every single day. I've seen the way he looks at you, the way you look at him. I'm not a fool.

Why do you treat me like I don't have a clue in the world as to what is going on in your life? Now I'm asking you, as a favor, if you have any respect for me at all as your mother, just tell me. Do you have feelings for this man?
I don't know. Maybe I do. I haven't given it much thought. Maybe I do.
Thank you. I'm glad you were finally honest with me. Now we can discuss what on earth you could possibly be thinking. Don't forget the ice.
(Cut to a man playing a guitar and singing as he walks across the street.
So, you're sure we need this many cans?
Oh, yeah, you need enough for two coats and touchups and little spots. No, I'm not sure.
Well we got the paint and the brushes and the tarps and all the other stuff the paint guy said we'd need, so I guess we're ready.
The only thing left to do is figure out when.
Yeah, I mean, you don't want the stuff sitting around. I don't know if paint goes bad, but judging by the smell of it when it's fresh, rotten paint would be really gross.
Don't you have dinner with your folks on Friday?
Well, yeah, but I can get out early for a special occasion.
(Lorelai leaves Luke and walks down the street. Rory catches her.
Jeez -- you think you got enough paint?
I know, I tried to tell him. So, dinner, thoughts?
OK. I need to stop at the market and get some fruit.
Yeah. Well that or a cold, but either way, I need some fruit.
(As they get to the market, they hear a motorcycle and turn around to look.
They're loud, they're dangerous. We should ban them from town.
Maybe we should set up barricades and ban all unwelcome strangers from crossing the border.
Well! Well, no we couldn't do that, that would be illegal.
Oh, got to get away from that noise.
Kill me and bury me with that bike.
That is a 2000 Indian, 80 horsepower, 5 speed close ratio Andrews transmission and I want to get one.
This is great! What are you doing here?
I'm here to see you. And your mom, who's not saying anything about as loud as a person can.
A word. Maybe there's a phrase in my future. OK, why is that man staring at me?
That's Taylor Doose. He owns the market. He knows all and sees all.
So, what's with the just showing up, Mr. Spontaneity Guy?
Well, my folks are back in Connecticut so I'm here to see them, and on the way I thought I'd stop by and surprise the Gilmore girls. Are you surprised?
Oh, the teeniest feather could knock me in the gutter.
So where would somebody find someplace to stay around here?
No, it's not that, I'm still surprised.
Why don't you stay with us for a couple of days?
Thanks, Lor. You won't even know I'm there. (to Rory) Hey, hop on.
(Rory gets on the back of Christopher's motorcycle and they ride down the street.
[Rory’s putting blankets on the couch for Christopher
He looks good don’t you think?
Do you think he’ll stay long?
Wouldn’t bet a lot of money on it.
Maybe we can get him to stay for a couple of weeks.
Absolutely - by weighting him down with blankets.
I just want him to be comfortable.
He’s gonna come and go as he pleases babe, you know that.
And no amount of bedding is gonna change that.
Yeah, but he’s never been to Stars Hollow before.
Well that means something’s gotta be different right?
Why don’t you just enjoy the time you’ve got ok?
[pause] Yeah, ok. I still think something is different though.
[coming down the stairs] That is the worst shower I have ever had. Water pressure keeps changing every two seconds. I’m fixing it tomorrow.
Hey you stay away from my shower.
We ordered chinese food. It should be here any minute.
Here [handing him a cup of coffee]
When I met her at Easter you said she could be the one.
The one to be gone by Memorial Day.
Oh I keep them happy. I keep them very happy.
I’m gonna go study before the food gets here.
I know, I like to get my weekend homework done and out of the way by Saturday night so then I can do extra-credit stuff on Sunday [leaves]
She’s a great kid Lor. I wish I could say I see more of myself in her other than we have similar left ear lobes, but she’s all you - chip off the old....perfect block.
Why the hell are you here?
Behold the queen of the subtle transition.
You’re gonna force me to lawyer up officer.
Ok look. I’ve been making some changes, especially my career and I think I finally have all my ducks lined up in a row.
I’ve been tying up loose ends in my life.
Do they make that much string?
You know you’ve always had that verbal thing, quick mind - it’s annoying.
So you’ve been tying up loose ends.

I don’t know how much your dad has told you but I’m on the verge of kind of a big success, it’s for real this time. I’ve got a company with an actual cash flow, I’ve got employees, I’ve got an accountant for God’s sake. He wears a tie and says words like ‘fiduciary’ and ‘ironically’. I mean it’s for real this time Lor.
I would love to believe it is.
[sighs] Why does your dad have more faith in my than you.
My father hit his head surfing Rincon a couple of years ago. His judgement’s a little off.
I’ve known you since I was six Chris. You’re the guy that crashed his Porsche two hours after his parents gave it to him for his 16th birthday.
And you were the girl in the Pinky Tuscadero t-shirt sitting right next to me.
Alright, having a blast then horrified.
Just listen to me will you?
I’m listening to you. Your life’s back on track, I think that’s great. And I appreciate you coming all the way out here, for the very first time might I add, to tell us that.
I didn’t come out here just to tell you that.
[sighs] There’s some things I need to do....to take care of.

I haven’t been enough a part of Rory’s life. So I wanna be around more, to be a pal she can depend on. I mean I’m not crazy, I know there’s already a life going on here and God knows she doesn’t need anyone besides you but....if you give me a chance....
I’ve always had the door to Rory open for you.
Well I wanna use it now. Is that ok?
coming into the living room] Hey, I forgot to ask you. Tomorrow morning I’m going to a softball game, do you wanna come?
Well ok, who’s game is it?

script.character: Rory: yeah dean. the game starts at 9

script.text: Uh, sure. It’s a date. [Rory leaves. To Lorelai] She has a Dean?
Well a single-celled organism crawled out of primordial ooze and that pretty much lead to Dean.
[chuckles] There’s a lot more than an earlobe resemblance there.
Good. Hey, thanks for the door thing.
[Luke’s pitching and Dean’s in the on deck circle
[to batter] You got it, you got the next one. Don’t worry about it. [batter strikes out]
Yes. We eat there practically every day.
Looks like we got out number three coming to the plate guys. [as Rory and Chris sit in the bleachers in front of Kirk]
I’d send your boys a little farther into the field Luke.
Why? Will they have a better view of you whiffing?
You know, the only way I’m not hitting it, is if you don’t have the strength to get it over the plate.
The truth of the matter is that you can’t pitch [pointing to Luke] and you can’t hit [point to Dean]. So this’ll be a terrific match up.
Don’t you have anything better to do with your Saturdays?

What can I say, I’m addicted to comedy. [to Rory and Chris] Half an hour they been playing and it’s tied zero - zero. [louder] Hey if you ever take this show on the road I got a name for you, zero and zero. Dean Zero and Luke Zero - get it?
I’m dumbing it down for you Alfalfa.
How long do these games last?
Till they get tired. And then they say the first team to get a run wins.
Yeah, it’s real professional down there. Hey Luke, does your husband play softball too?
Alright that’s it. [starts for the bleachers]
Um....I’m getting a page. I’ve gotta go. [jumps off the bleachers and starts running.]
Hey. Dean this is my dad. Dad, this is Dean.
So do you live in the area?
No I had some time so I rode my bike out from Berkley.
I gotta go. [to Rory] I’ll see you later. [to Christopher] I was nice meeting you. [runs onto the field]
[to Luke] Hey, uh, next run wins alright?
[Michel and Sookie are laughing as Lorelai enters
Wow! I have never seen you two enjoy a pleasant moment together.
Oh you have seen us enjoy a pleasant moment!
You have to admit, they are few and far between.
I’m just saying, it’s refreshing you know? It’s not the usual ‘Grr’ that’s all.
Through no fault of yours? I’m sorry, but you’re the one that’s so....I don’t know.
Oh I think you do otherwise you wouldn’t have started saying it.
Oh no, I’m just saying it’s refreshing to see you two just - oh yeah.
You - get in here and tell me the happenings at home.
I’m assuming you mean ‘did we get our toaster fixed’ and no, it’s been cold pop-tarts for a week, it’s like a damn Dicken’s novel.
I’m not talking about the toaster, I’m talking about the man.
So what’s it like having him around the house all the time?
Well it’s, um, a little weird. We have fewer clean towels than usual.
Come on give me something. Tell me how you feel, I’m dying here.
Honestly, I’ve been trying to figure out how this makes me feel since he asked me to take off my shirt the other day.
No, it was a - kind of a ‘hello’ kind of thing.

Yeah. I mean I have not seen this man since last Christmas right. We hear from him maybe once a week - maybe. And then all of a sudden he’s here in my town and Rory’s running around all excited and he’s sleeping on the couch and I’m thinking ‘should I be mad, should I send him to a hotel’ but then he smiles and it’s....Christopher.
I mean not matter how many years go by, no matter how long I don’t see him for, whenever I do, it’s always....Christopher. What do I do with this? [holding up biscotti]

[sighs] This man knows all my secrets. All of my bad girl moments happened with him - my worst fashion choices, my big hair days, the wearing of the Bonnie-Bell lipsmackers around my neck - it was all with Christopher.
So do you think you two will -
I don’t know I - he wants to be involved with Rory. He wants to spend more time with her, be a pal.
This is the town flower shop. Um, over there is a good pizza place. That’s the stationary store and that’s Al’s Pancake world.

He switched to international cuisine a couple of years ago, and dropped the pancakes. He would’ve changed the name but he had already printed like a million napkins with the original name so he just kept it.
He kind of hops around. Last month it was his salute to Paraguay.
Rory! Honey! How are you sweetie?
Great. Miss Patty, this is my dad, Christopher.

You’re Rory’s father, well, well, well. You know Christopher, we’re all like Rory’s parents around here and I’m one of her mothers. And since you’re her father, well that would make us....a couple. [laughing] A couple of what I don’t know.
Ok, well we’ve got to be going.
Yes well, come back and see me.
[laughing] Bye. [As Rory and Chris cross the street she takes out her cell phone and dials]
[As Rory and Chris pass the market
Well you must be Rory’s father.
Taylor Doose, grocer to Stars Hollow.
Very nice to meet you. [they keep walking. To Rory] News travels fast around here.
Yes it does. [behind them you see Taylor dialing.]
Bookstore. Good. Come on.[they enter. Jackson and Andrew are there]
Boy I gotta tell you, did they get your description wrong.
Oh yeah, much more George Clooney than Brad Pitt. Hey Andrew.
Don’t you think he’s much more George Clooney than Brad Pitt?
I’m going with the Billy Crudup comparison myself.
I don’t see it. Well maybe from the side. Hey do you mind?
[Jackson grabs him and turns him from one side profile to the other
What? Uh, no, not at all.
Well there’s a little Crudup in there. Huh, well it’s nice to meet you, whoever you look like.
Nice to meet you. [tugs at Rory as they go down an aisle] Ok, I’m kidnapping you and getting you out of here.
Yeah, I’m sure all lunatics have the best intentions. Ok, so I hear you like books.
Well I would like you to pick something out and let my buy it for you.
Dad you don’t have to buy me anything.
Come on, what’s the book of your dreams right now?
Well that would definitely be the Compact Oxford English Dictionary, but dad -
Excuse me - one Compact Oxford English Dictionary please.
Dad no, it costs a fortune.
You need something to remember this visit by.
ANDREW [bringing a very large and heavy book] Here you go
Holy mother. This is the monolith from 2001.
It has every word ever recorded in the English language plus origins and earliest usage.
You sure you wouldn’t rather have a car, they weigh about the same. Here you go. [handing over a credit card]
This is so nice of you.
Yeah, well I’ve got a lot of things to make up for.
[whispering] Uh, I’m sorry Christopher, your credit card has been rejected.
Rejected? What are you talking about?
I could run it through again if you’d like.
Uh, no. He doesn’t need to run it throug hagain.
Could you maybe hold that for us? I’ll come back tomorrow with another card.
Thanks. Come on. [they leave the bookstore. Outside] Now you’ll really remember me.
I didn’t want it that much anyways.
Hey, listen, don’t tell your mom about this ok?

[standing with his back to them talking to a group of people] Yes it is her real dad. He seems very nice. Kind of a folky, poppy, urban, scruffy look to him. And obviously there’s some money mixed in there because he’s got that you know, money nose. And - [someone clears their throat. Jackson turns around and see Rory and Chris standing there. He touches his touque and runs off. ]
So Rory was at the game today.
Yeah she was with some guy.
No, I know that punk. Some older guy.
Oh, that would’ve been her dad.
The guy who impregnated me with Rory - yes.
Oh, well, he did a good job.
Now this has taken a very weird turn.
Oh hi, where were you? [as she kisses Rory]
Well we saw Al’s Paraguayan pancake house, we were stalked by several towns people and apparently I look like Billy Crudup.
Take it up with Jackson. [phone rings]
Ah, ah, ah, ah,. Hey, hey, hey, hey. [points to the no cell phone sign]
Uh-huh [pause] Well actually I’m sitting here with your girls. [pause] Sure. [to Lorelai, handing her the phone] She wants to speak to you.
[gasps] What?! I didn’t know! Although coincidently I’m sitting across an amazing Christopher hologram.
Well I had this wonderful idea. Christopher’s parents are in town too. You remember Straub and Francine don’t you?
Well I called them up and invited them to dinner. They said they are free to join us all on Friday night.
Yes. You, Rory, Christopher, your father.
Well I should say so. We haven’t all been together since the two of you were children. And Straub and Francine haven’t seen Rory since she was a baby.
It’ll be like a wonderful reunion - all of us together again. I never thought it would happen.
[The three of them standing in front of the door
Ladies and gentlemen, the drama king and queen of Connecticut.
Oh my God! You’re here. Christopher, look at you!
I am so glad to see you, I didn’t hear the doorbell.
It’s ok mom, look, not a rapist among us.
Not since you gave us a key.
Well mom, I’m starving to death. Is that enough of an emergency for you?
Well, Richard’s in the living room, come on in. He’s dying to see you.
[whispers to Chris] It’s a setup giving me that key. It’s a key, it meant to be used, it’s my parents house. Shut up.
Hello Rory. Lorelai. Christopher old boy how are you? My gosh it’s good to see you!
Well I’m better than most, not as good as some.
Aha! You speak the truth young man! I have made martini’s. So Christopher, tell me about your business.
Oh Richard, let the poor boy relax.
Well I simply want to find out how it’s going.
It’s uh - it’s going great Richard. I’m almost afraid to jinx it by telling you good it’s going.
Oh, that is wonderful. I always knew you had it in you. You have a splash of greatness as my mother would say. You’ve always had that splash of greatness.
Mm. I’d like another splash of greatness if you don’t mind.[getting another martini]
Oh Richard. Isn’t Rory the spitting image of Christopher?
I just hope you inherit your father’s business sense also my dear.
I know one thing for sure- you certainly have your father’s musical talent.
Mom, neither of these two have any musical talent.
You know the opening lick to ‘Smoke on the Water’.
And I’ve since mastered the opening like to ‘Jumping Jack Flash’.
I’m a....Chuck Berry man myself. [Lorelai laughs almost spitting out her drink] Something wrong?
I would never have guessed that that last sentence would ever come out of your mouth.
Yes, Chuck Berry. He was all the rage when I was in school.
Do you remember when you two were what - ten and you put on that adorable show for us.
Lucy, Schroeder, you laying on the coffee table.
You pretending it was a piano. God, why is that remembered?
Because it was such a wonderful production.
I don’t know if it was a production mom. It was just one song.
Did you write that? That was really very good.
Dad, that’s from ‘You’re a good man Charlie Brown’ It’s a famous musical.
Well I thought Christopher might have written it, he’s a very talented man.
That would be Straub and Francine. [leaves to answer the door]
[whispers to Rory] Ha, ha your turn.
I haven’t seen your parents in quite a number of years. We were practically inseparable for a while. [leaves]
This is weird. These are my other grandparents. I don’t even know them. What do I call them?
Just, uh, call them Straub and Francine. Call them Mr and Mrs Hayden. Sir and Ma’am? Why don’t you just avoid calling them anything.
Mr and Mrs Hayden, long time no see.
I am thanks. You remember Rory. You haven’t seen her in quite a while.
I think she was just beginning to speak in complete sentences.
So not for two years then. [Hayden’s look at her] She’s obviously been talking a long time so I was making a humorous comment sometimes referred to as a ‘joke’.
I see you haven’t changed Lorelai.
Uh, Straub, Francine, how about a martini?
Well Straub, how is retirement treating you?
Yes do tell us about the Bahamas.
You can get an entire island there for the cost of a decent house here.
How about you Richard, any thoughts of retirement crossing your mind?
Oh Straub, if only you could talk him into it. I’ve given up.
We’re very pleased about Christopher’s business success out in California.
Yes, it’s taken a while but it seems to be finally coming together. Seems to be.
[clears her throat]Straub and Fran - [clears her throat] Mr. and Mrs. um....are you enjoying your time here, um....you...two?
[to Lorelai] That she got from you.
How old are you young lady?
Dangerous age for girls [Lorelai looks at him]
Rory is a very special child - excellent student, very bright.
You should have a talk with her Straub, she could give you a run for your money.
[Straub looks at Rory, Rory looks uncomfortable unsure what to do
Well I think my money’s safe.
He’s stupid and his face is too tiny for his head and I just want to toss him out.
That is the leader of our country young lady.
His face is too tiny for his head, what kind of thing is that to say?
I see your daughter is just as out of control as ever.
Pop please. Let’s try and keep it civil.
Tell me Lorelai, what have you been doing with your life anyway, besides hating successful businessmen. I’m just curious.
Why don’t we all go into the dining room?
Well uh, Straub, I run an inn near Stars Hollow.
Nice to see you found your calling.
And is your life everything you hoped it would be?
Because it seems to me you might not want to take such a haughty tone when you announce to the world that you work in a hotel.
Well there’s nothing wrong with where I work.
Straub please. I’m getting a headache.
Come on Richard, lead us into the dining room, now.
If you had attended a university as your parents had planned and as we planned in vain for Christopher, you might have aspired to something more than a blue collared position.
And I wouldn’t give a damn about you derailing your life if you hadn’t swept my son along with you.
[to Rory] Honey go into the next room. Go, go.
I’m going to have to echo Christopher’s call for civility here. A mutual mistake was make many years ago by these two, but they have come a long way since.

A mutual mistake Richard? This whole evening is ridiculous. We’re supposed to sit here like one big happy family and pretend that the damage that was done is over, gone? I don’t care about how good a student you say that girl is....

Our son was bound for Princeton. Every Hayden male attended Princeton including myself, but it all stopped with Christopher. It’s a humiliation we’ve had to live with every day, all because you seduced him into ruining his life. She had that baby and ended his future.
[grabbing Straub’s arm] You recant that Straub!
You owe my daughter an apology.
How dare you?! [grabbing Straub] How dare you?!
How dare you come into my house and insult my daughter!
Whoa, whoa, what is going on here? [putting himself between them]
Shame on you Straub, shame on you for opening all this up again.
My daughter is very successful at what she does.
You’re not leaving. I’m kicking you out. [All four leave the room. Lorelai and Christopher and standing in the middle]
And you brought up Bush because?
It seemed like a good idea at the time. Wow.
[Pan to study. Richard sitting reading. Lorelai enters
Dad? Dad....can I get you something to eat?
Thank me? For what? [Lorelai turns back.]

Well for what you did in there. I’m....I’m just unbelievably touched and grateful for what you said to him, for defending me like that. I know it was hard for you because, well....but thank you. [starts to leave]
Why do you think I did it? [Lorelai turns back.]
Why do you think I did it?
I don’t know. Um, out of protectiveness I guess.
You don’t need to be protected Lorelai. You’ve made it very clear that you can look after yourself and that you need nothing from anyone.
A member of my family was being attacked. The very Gilmore name was being attacked. I will not stand for that not under any circumstances.
Ok, well it doesn’t really matter why you did it.
Yes it does matter why I did it! It matters greatly! Lorelai what are you going to take away from this? That everything that happened in the past is suddenly fine because I defended you?
That the hell that you put your mother and I through for the past 16 years is suddenly washed away? Well it’s not.
We’ve all been through hell dad.
I had to tell my friends, my colleagues, that my only daughter, the brightest in her class, was pregnant and was leaving school.
And then you run away and treat us like lepers. Your mother couldn’t get out of bed for a month. Did you know that? Did you?
We did nothing to deserve that. Nothing to earn that!
I get it. I’m horrible. So why don’t you disown me and adopt Christopher, you love him.

Don’t be a martyr Lorelai. And don’t be naïve. Do you think I love the boy who got my daughter pregnant? I wanted to kill him! I would have too with my bare hands. But there’s a proper procedure to be followed in a situation like this.
Christopher was willing to follow the procedure we laid out, you weren’t.
What about what I wanted Dad? Didn’t that matter to you at all?
Sometimes one has to sacrifice something in order to do what is right.
I feel indescribably sad for you right now, dad.
Well save your emotions Lorelai. I’ve had my fill of them tonight.
So, um, we just end it here. Nothing....resolved?
There you are. I was wondering where you went.
No, it’s nothing to be sorry about. Can I get you something?
[holding up a pop can] I’m fine.
Oh that’s hardly dinner. Well that was quite a bit of excitement tonight.
None of this means anything Rory.

Straub is actually a good man. Very smart. He was one of the top lawyers in his field - a very arcane aspect of International law. And he’s always been so active in his community. His charity work has never diminished over the years. Oh let’s face it - he’s a big ass. [Rory laughs] Rory, I know you heard a lot of talk about various disappointments this evening and I know you’ve heard a lot of talk about it in the past. But I want to make this very clear - you, young lady, your person and your existence have never ever been - not even for a second - included in that list. Do you understand me?
Good now eat up. [hands her a plate of leftovers]
[Pan to balcony outside Lorelai’s old room. Lorelai sitting crying.
You look great [coming out onto the balcony.]
Yeah, well, I look the way I feel wiseguy.
That was....that was a memorable evening.
Oh yes, it was beautiful in there. We should commemorate it with an oil painting or a severed head or something.
Next time we get this group together we’re gonna have to frisk for weapons.
Employ six individual cones of silence [Lorelai laughs] Boy the old balcony is still the same isn’t it?
Perfect hide-out - totally private. We spent a lot of time out here.
Sneaking dad’s telescope, scanning the sky for alien ships.
Huh. And then when we were older, scanning the neighbors houses for naked people.
[laughing] Mrs. Dominski undulating in her big fat underalls is forever carved into my brain.
[laughing] And in mine. [takes out a tequila bottle] here’s to Mrs. Dominski’s underalls.
Aw, you’re holding out on me.
[takes a drink] Take it. And in an effort to further chronicle this balcony’s history, we are now in the immediate vicinity of the spot upon which was Rory’s initial eminations.
Yes we are. Here’s to Rory. [takes a drink]
The bright spot in all the darkness.
You know even if you hadn’t gotten pregnant and everything had gone as planned, I still never would have make it through Princeton.
Yeah, well that’s why you’re you and I’m not.

[Pan to Luke’s where Luke is waiting for Lorelai. He gives up and goes inside. Pan back to the balcony where Christopher and Lorelai are kissing as they take off each other’s clothes. Pan to them putting back on their clothes.
Yeah, yeah I’m a little wigged.

(Miss Patty narrates a story in the background as the camera pans around town as locals prepare for a festival.

This, boys and girls, is the story of true love. A beautiful girl from one county; a handsome boy from another. They meet and they fall in love. Separated by distance and by parents who did not approve of the union, the young couple dreamed of a day that they could be together. They wrote each other beautiful letters. Letters of longing and passion. Letters full of promises and plans for the future. Soon the separation proved too much for either one of them to bear. So, one night, cold and black with no light to guide them, they both snuck out of their homes and ran away as fast as they could. It was so dark out that they were both soon lost and it seemed as if they would never find each other. Finally, the girl dropped to her knees, tears streaming down her lovely face. 'Oh, my love. Where are you? How will I find you?' Suddenly, a band of stars appeared in the sky. These stars shone so brightly they lit up the entire countryside. The girl jumped to her feet and followed the path of the stars until finally she found herself standing right where the town gazebo is today. And there waiting for her was her one true love, who had also been led here by the blanket of friendly stars. [Camera stops on Miss Patty's dance studio, where she is telling the story to a group of children.] And that, my friends, is the story of how Stars Hollow came to be, and why we celebrate that fateful night every year at about this time.
